The prospect of United rebuilding their stadium has raised the prospect of where they would play in the interim. A senior staff member said before the strategic review commenced that there was "no chance" they would consider playing home matches at the Etihad Stadium, Manchester City's home.

Plans were presented to United before the Glazer family announced a strategic review of the club in November 2022. It was announced the Ineos Group agreed a 25% stakeholding in United on Christmas Eve.

With structural and personnel changes expected once the Ineos Group receive regulatory approval from the Premier League, it is unclear if Populous's proposals will be sanctioned by Ineos chairman Sir Jim Ratcliffe.

headline: Mason Mount suffered unexpected double blow during Manchester United injury absence
body: Man Utd could soon welcome back their £60m summer signing but his role in the team is not so sure.

Mason Mount will soon be available again for Manchester United. You might not notice right away. He has been sidelined since November 11 with a calf problem and last started a Premier League game on October 7. It's not exactly the return Erik ten Hag hoped for when he identified him as his top midfield target a year ago.

Mount joined United from Chelsea for £60million in the last summer window and has been 'struggling' with injury issues since August. It begs the question of how much United knew of the extent of his injury issues before he joined.

The England international did not start in any of Chelsea's last 18 matches of the 2022–23 campaign due to a pubis injury, and he has started nine games in the last year, completing 90 minutes only once. It would be a surprise if he played a full game before the end of the campaign.

That's not because of further fitness concerns, but because of the fact he won't be starting matches in the first place. What is so alarming is that even when he is fit, it is hard to see exactly where he fits into the United side, a problem that has worsened during his spell on the sidelines.
Mount was signed to be the link man in midfield, tasked with progressing the play from defence to attack and bringing composure to the role. Kobbie Mainoo has proven to be that man instead.

In the five matches that Mount and Casemiro played together at the start of the campaign, United struggled for a midfield presence, with the duo struggling to match the physicality of the Premier League.
Mount's case is again not helped by the fact teenager Mainoo has shone with his physicality as well as his ball-playing ability, showcasing both silk and steel during his senior breakthrough.

The former Chelsea midfielder is now a backup at best for United, behind Mainoo in the progressive midfield role and still behind club captain Bruno Fernandes in the more advanced attacking midfield role too.

It is not necessarily the biggest blow to have a player like Mount on the bench, though it once again undermines Ten Hag's own eye for talent and the huge amount of money invested in a squad player, which left them short of funds to strengthen the squad in the January window.

Mount is also not helped by the fact United look to have finally solved their right-wing dilemma. Up until late December, there was no outstanding candidate to occupy the right-flank role, a position that he had shone in during his time at Chelsea.

The 25-year-old looked like an ideal big-game player thanks to his energy, pressing ability, and defensive discipline, but Ten Hag will favour the attacking threat of Alejandro Garnacho in that position instead.

There could still be occasions in which United decide Mount is worthy of a position switch out wide to help them against some strong possession-based opponents, though there are few opportunities for that to be tested between now and the end of the season.
As he nears a return to injury, Mount will be desperate to make up for lost time. The bad news for him is that others made the most of it instead.

headline: The Ineos to-do list at Manchester United has got shorter
body: Sir Jim Ratcliffe is getting to work on transforming Man Utd but his plans for long-term progress have been made easier since the deal was announced.

When the deal handing Ineos 25% of Manchester United was confirmed on Christmas Eve their to-do list was both long and unappealing. The beginning of the end for the Glazers was toasted by supporters over the festive period, but the situation remained grim.

Defeat to Nottingham Forest in the final game of 2023 made it five defeats in December for Erik ten Hag’s side and while Sir Jim Ratcliffe and Sir Dave Brailsford were busy getting to work behind the scenes, what was unfolding in front of them on the pitch would have been causing more immediate concern.

Ratcliffe is still waiting for regulatory approval for his minority investment to go through but his fingerprints are all over every major decision United have made in the last six-and-a-half weeks, most of them focused on bringing long-term success back to Old Trafford.

But while Brailsford’s review of football operations at the club and Ratcliffe’s attempts to put the football front and centre once again were worthy attempts at bringing some kind of order back to the club, their task was only going to be made more difficult by getting the reins in a season that was threatening to become an unmitigated disaster.

On Christmas Eve they inherited a manager under pressure, a £72million striker who couldn’t score and a team that lost as often as they won. They were out of Europe already and threatening to not even qualify for continental competition in 2024/25.

With their compliance with the Premier League’s Profit and Sustainability rules (PSR) already tight, such a scenario was daunting. It would have a significant affect on this summer’s budget at a time when United need to spend to get back in the top four.

But as the day the keys are officially cut for Ineos gets closer, the situation is looking up. Perhaps the two short-term scenarios they least wanted to countenance are no longer looking quite so problematic.

Ratcliffe and Brailsford’s initial discussions with Ten Hag were positive and results are improving, as the Dutchman suggested they would when the injury situation eased. He isn’t out of the woods yet, the collapse at Wolves before Kobbie Mainoo’s intervention was concerning and although the win at West Ham was an example of the clinical finishing they’ve been missing, they still allowed the visitors to have 22 shots at Old Trafford.

But four wins in five games have eased the pressure on Ten Hag and suggested he might just be the man to oversee the Ineos era on the pitch. The last thing Ratcliffe wanted was to have to consider a change in manager while looking for a new sporting director. He desperately wants - and needs - Ten Hag to steady the ship and reassert his own credentials.

With no prospect of managerial change to consider, the planning for the summer transfer window becomes easier - especially with a new sporting director appointed in plenty of time. United do need to get away from allowing Ten Hag the level of control he has over recruitment decisions, with too many of his signings not working out.

But one that is certainly paying off is the decision to back Hojlund this summer. The signing of an inexperienced 20-year-old striker to lead the line at United was a gamble but that roll of the dice is certainly looking better.

United still need another striker this summer, but Hojlund has now scored in four successive Premier League appearances and is up to 10 goals for the season. He is beginning to look like the frontman Ten Hag and football director John Murtough thought he could be.

If the Dane can maintain that form until the end of the season, then the focus this summer will be on signing competition for him, rather than needing to consider another elite striker to score the goals required at United. Hojlund suddenly looks like he might be that man and that change in status could save the club millions this summer.

With no decision to be made over a new manager and no need to break the bank on a first-choice striker, the in-tray for Ineos could be looking better. It will allow Ratcliffe to focus on infrastructure developments at Old Trafford and Carrington and on getting the right personnel in the right positions. The weeks between confirmation of the deal and approval from the Premier League have gone as well as could have been hoped for.

headline: Sir Jim Ratcliffe holds meetings at Manchester United training ground and Old Trafford
body: Sir Jim Ratcliffe has been in Manchester again as the Ineos Group awaits regulatory approval for their 25% stakeholding in Man United.
Sir Jim Ratcliffe visited Manchester United's Carrington training complex on Monday as he continues to plan for assuming control of the club's football operations.

Ratcliffe, who attended the memorial service for the Munich air disaster at Old Trafford on Tuesday, has now made three separate visits to Manchester since the Ineos Group agreed to take a 25% stakeholding in the club.
A source said Ratcliffe is "getting down to business" at United as Ineos awaits regulatory approval for their stake from the Premier League.

Ratcliffe, 71, was flanked at Old Trafford by the Ineos sporting director Sir Dave Brailsford, who has been a near-ever present at United games over the last six weeks. Ratcliffe and Brailsford were not visible during the home win against West Ham on Sunday, though.

Other figures from Ineos are understood to be spending extensive time in Manchester as the petrochemicals group continue their audit of United amid planned structural change. Club staff have also flown to Monaco, where Ratcliffe resides, for additional meetings.
EXCLUSIVE: Arteta Arsenal comparison fuelling United's belief in Ten Hag

United have already prised Omar Berrada from Manchester City to become their chief executive in the summer. Berrada, Brailsford and Ineos sporting chief executive Jean-Claude Blanc are expected to be the most visible figures of the new hierarchy.

Sporting a maroon club tie and a white shirt under a navy Chesterfield overcoat and shielded by an umbrella, Ratcliffe was stood next to Manchester mayor Andy Burnham as United remembered the 23 men who were killed in Munich 66 years ago.

United have held meetings within the last two years about whether to enhance or rebuild Old Trafford. Joel Glazer, the co-chairman, is understood to have expressed his preference to renovate the stadium.

Glazer has not attended a United match since the Champions League quarter-final first leg defeat to Barcelona in April 2019. No member of the Glazer family has ever been present for one of the fan-led Munich memorial services.
Ratcliffe, born in Failsworth, was five when eight United players were killed on their journey back from a European Cup quarter-final win over Red Star Belgrade in February 1958.

headline: Lisandro Martinez has told Erik ten Hag what he wanted to hear amid Man United injury blow
body: Manchester United defender Lisandro Martinez sustained a knee injury against West Ham and will be out for around two months
Lisandro Martinez will hope it's third time lucky when he returns for Manchester United's run-in.

The defender is set to be out for eight weeks after sustaining a knee injury against West Ham on Sunday. It's his third prolonged injury absence in under a year and is a huge blow to Erik ten Hag as he tries to steer United into the Champions League places.

Martinez is a key lieutenant for Ten Hag, having followed the manager from Ajax. His position in the defence is pivotal to United's style of play and the centre-back could now be absent for nine first-team fixtures across the Premier League and FA Cup.

He's already missed 34 matches since signing for United through two separate injuries but the combative 26-year-old has twice returned to the coalface in fine fettle. He will hope his next comeback is more permanent.

Either way, Martinez won't be a despondent figure on the sidelines. He'll knuckle down with his trademark tenacity to get back to full fitness at the first available opportunity while he's already outlined how he can use an enforced absence to build his knowledge in other areas.

“It is part of football also and we need to accept it, be humble," he said, speaking in a club interview in December while sidelined. "It is a time to work even harder, in the gym, improving, doing analysis, doing tactics, in the things that we can improve on the pitch.
“As a person as well, I love to improve that part because, for everybody, if you improve then automatically you will see it on the pitch."

Martinez will be supported by the medical staff at United and his teammates, as well as friends and family. And the World Cup winner is well-versed in overcoming quickfire injuries having only been fully fit for a number of weeks at the start of the campaign between his two absences.

“It is tough, so tough," he added of that time. "Especially when you had two injuries, almost six or seven months, it is really, really tough. But I feel strong from my mind. I get really good values from my family, to never give up, so this has only made me even stronger. It is tough, so tough, but there are no excuses."
All the latest Manchester United news, views and transfer gossip on our dedicated blog

United will be determined to narrow the gap with Tottenham Hotspur, who currently sit fifth, meanwhile Villa will be hoping to break into the top-three. It's poised to be a huge game, but the visitors will have to make do without Lisandro Martinez.

The 26-year-old defender has already missed a large chunk of the season due to a foot injury he suffered in September, and now he's set for another extended spell on the sidelines. Elsewhere, there's plenty of life left in the rumour mill.

Everton defender Jarred Branthwaite and Crystal Palace ace Michael Olise have both recently been heavily linked with moves to Old Trafford. A stadium which could be given a new lick of paint very soon – so stay tuned for more!
With that being said, stay with us at Manchester Evening News as we plate up all the latest news, views and transfer gossip on our dedicated United blog!
Speaking on Sky Sports, Dwight Yorke said: "He’s still on that borrowed time, he still needs time, but I’m glad that he’s got a couple of goals. That may settle him down.

"Another question, what are his strengths? Because I still don’t know what his strengths are. Often enough, when you do your due diligence about players and you're playing £75m for a player – is he fast, can he head it, can he shoot, can he dribble…?"

The former Manchester United striker added: "If you’re coming in it doesn’t matter how good you are, how young you are or how old you are, you’re going to be struggling in a team that is struggling, that is inconsistent.
"I feel for the kid and I think there will be some challenging times ahead for him..."
Speaking on the Stick to Football podcast, brought to you by Sky Bet, Jamie Carragher said: "Marcus Rashford doesn’t need to be like Roy Keane, he must lead and show character in a different way.

"Someone like Steven Gerrard, who was a completely different player to Marcus Rashford. Someone like me who would be shouting and screaming at people, at the referee and other players, and Stevie showed leadership through his whole ability and the respect he had from the other players.
"I’m not saying Rashford needs to go round shouting at everyone, but his body language needs to change and being the person, you want him to be when someone becomes a leader."

Manchester United have been advised a new build is the best option as they consider an upgrade of Old Trafford. The Manchester Evening News understands renovation of the 114-year-old stadium would be complicated due to the railway lines and the existing structures.

Although sources have suggested enhancing the stadium would be more cost-efficient than rebuilding it, the expense would still be considerable and more time-consuming. The Red Devils would also be hit by reduced capacity crowds, as they were when the north stand, now the Sir Alex Ferguson Stand, was rebuilt in 1995.

A new Old Trafford would be a higher capital cost but provide a better return on the investment and could be constructed while Old Trafford is still in use, as Tottenham did with White Hart Lane while their new stadium was under construction next door. That would prevent United from playing in front of reduced-capacity crowds.
Speaking to Betfair, Dimitar Berbatov said: "It's exciting to watch players like Mainoo, especially when they have such huge talent, but one step at a time. Don't jump when you need to walk first.
"Let's not get carried away and start talking about Mainoo getting picked by Gareth Southgate and going to this summer's Euros with England.
"Obviously Ten Hag trusts Mainoo and knows how to manage him so everything else will follow in time. We need to just enjoy what's happening now and not get carried away just yet. Let Mainoo play."
Veteran goalkeeper Joe Lewis has been sporadically involved in Manchester United first-team training since joining up with the club to maintain fitness in December.
The Manchester Evening News revealed before Christmas that Lewis had been taking part in academy training at Carrington to keep fit after the expiry of his contract with Aberdeen.

It's understood Lewis spoke with one of the United coaches in requesting to come in and train. That arrangement has continued and he took part in first-team training this week to make up numbers in preparation for Sunday's game against Aston Villa.

Kobbie Mainoo has sent a heartwarming message to a grieving Manchester United fan whose father sadly passed away last week. The 18-year-old midfielder received a tweet from a supporter, thanking him for netting the winner against Wolves on Thursday evening.
It was a night to remember for the teenage sensation, but his strike meant a lot more to one fan who was able to celebrate one more stoppage-time winner with his father.

In an interview with Dutch outlet De Telegraaf, Wim Kieft suggested that Brian Brobbey's agent just wants to make a 'quick profit' from his form. The Ajax icon said: "Here, in his own familiar environment, (Brobbey) is developing much better.

"But you are not immediately ready for a move to a top European club after one good season in the Eredivisie. There are plenty of rumours going around. But here, in the Eredivisie, he plays against FC Volendam, Excelsior, Go Ahead Eagles, Heracles Almelo and RKC.

"In England or Spain, you are like Gakpo and Depay, against top defenders," Kieft added. "Maybe his agent wants to make a quick profit from his current form. But, for Brobbey himself, another season of the Eredivisie would be best from a sporting perspective.

"At Ajax, he can become even stronger. Score more, gain more confidence, play even better and then he will join a major foreign club as an established name. Don’t let money be the determining factor."

Speaking to Betfair, Dimitar Berbatov said: "The injury Lisandro Martinez suffered was ridiculously unlucky. I sympathise with him and know how he feels. The only thing he must do now is just try to get back on the pitch as soon as possible.

"His absence is a blow to United because we all know how important Martinez is to the team. He's always fighting tirelessly to give his best for United, but this is how football works sometimes. It can be cruel.
"Now with the injury, things have changed slightly. Maybe they need to try and find someone at the back for next season, but we can't think too much about the summer window now.
"There's plenty of time until that comes. For now, they have to use what's available and manage the situation as best they possibly can..."

Speaking to Danish magazine Tipsbladet, Thomas Frank has admitted that Ivan Toney will 'most likely be sold in the summer'. The Brentford boss said: "It's quite obvious that Ivan Toney will most likely be sold in the summer.

"It can be expensive to sell your best player, but on the other hand, I also know that by summer, he'll only have a year left on his contract with us. We also know what he's worth. I don't think there are many strikers in the world who are better than him right now.
Frank added: "He's a really good striker who is in his prime footballing age. Personally, as a coach, I would prefer to keep Toney, but one day it could be fun to see him at a top team.
"This winter, we actually had no bids for him, but it would surprise me if there aren't a lot of clubs interested in him."
Speaking on the Stick to Football podcast, brought to you by Sky Bet, Jamie Carragher said: "Marcus Rashford doesn’t need to be like Roy Keane, he must lead and show character in a different way.

"Someone like Steven Gerrard, who was a completely different player to Marcus Rashford. Someone like me who would be shouting and screaming at people, at the referee and other players, and Stevie showed leadership through his whole ability and the respect he had from the other players.
"I’m not saying Rashford needs to go round shouting at everyone, but his body language needs to change and being the person, you want him to be when someone becomes a leader..."

Speaking to Betfair, Dimitar Berbatov said: "I saw Bruno was the latest Premier League player linked with Saudi Arabia. Unless the offer is so good that you can't turn it down - and that wouldn't be difficult for the Saudis - he will not leave the club.
"He's the captain, creating a lot of chances on the pitch and everyone looks up to him. I don't see him leaving the club in the foreseeable future."
Fernandes has been an excellent servant for United in recent years. The 29-year-old midfielder sees his contract at Old Trafford expire in 2026.

Manchester United have held meetings within the last two years about whether to enhance or rebuild Old Trafford. Joel Glazer, the co-chairman, is understood to have expressed his preference to renovate the stadium.
Despite this, he has not attended a match since the Champions League quarter-final first-leg defeat to Barcelona in April 2019...

The Ineos Group has moved a step closer to receiving regulatory approval for their 25% investment in Manchester United. The Red Devils held an emergency general meeting on Monday and a vote was held to allow the Class B shares to be transferred to Ineos chairman Sir Jim Ratcliffe.

The Securities and Exchange Commission filings that were published on Tuesday stated: "Approval of a special resolution to replace the existing amended and restated memorandum and articles of association of the Company with a new amended and restated memorandum and articles of association to, among other things, provide for certain transfers of Class B ordinary shares without conversion of such shares into Class A ordinary shares."

Welcome back to the Manchester Evening News blog dedicated to bringing you all the latest Manchester United news, updates and transfer gossip as it happens LIVE from Old Trafford! Erik ten Hag is preparing for a trip to Villa Park this weekend...
There were some fourth round replays in the FA Cup tonight with three clubs booking their place in the fifth round.
United are already in that stage and will take on eith Bristol City or Nottingham Forest who play their fourth round replay on Wednesday night.
Tuesday night's results are as follows:
Southampton 3-0 Watford
Coventry 4-1 Sheffield Wednesday
Plymouth 1-4 Leeds (AET)
Manchester United will target players who are entering the final 12 months of their contract during the summer transfer window, according to reports.
ESPN claim that United will have money to spend in the transfer window, but as a way of managing finances, the club will look to target players whose contracts are expiring.
Players in that situation are usually available at a cheaper price due to the selling club being worries about losing him for nothing just 12 months later.
The likes of Joshua Kimmich, Jonathan Davis and Kaphren Thuram are named as potential targets who are out of contract in the summer of 2025.
Aston Villa boss Unai Emery has confirmed that defender Ezri Konsa will not be fit to play against United after suffering a knee injury.
The centre-back was injured when colliding with the post during the 5-0 win on Saturday evening. He is now set to miss the next few weeks.
"He is injured. He has a knee sprain and he is going to be not available for three or four weeks more or less.
Mason Greenwood is attracting plenty of interest from teams in Spain and Atletico Madrid are the latest club to join the queue.
According to The Telegraph, Greenwood has joined Atletico's summer striker shortlist. One to keep an eye on this summer.
Joshua Kimmich is one man who could be on his way to Old Trafford in the summer.
According to ESPN, Kimmich is one of three players on Erik ten Hag's radar. OGC Nice's Khephren Thuram and Lille striker Jonathan David are said to be on the same shortlist.
Sir Jim Ratcliffe is expected to oversee a huge transfer window at the club.
Veteran goalkeeper Joe Lewis has been sporadically involved in United first-team training since joining up with the club to maintain fitness in December.
The Manchester Evening News revealed before Christmas that Lewis had been taking part in academy training at Carrington to keep fit after the expiry of his contract with Aberdeen.
It's understood Lewis spoke with one of the United coaches in requesting to come in and train.
A report from The i says Michael Olise and Jarrad Branthwaite will be top targets for United this summer as Sir Jim Ratcliffe eyes a new transfer policy.
Ratcliffe has reportedly met with the club's data department to help build the best metrics platform in sport to help with scouting.

United need defensive reinforcements this summer with Raphael Varane set to leave at the end of his contract in June as things stand. Branthwaite is being tracked by multiple clubs, as is Olise who could be spied as an alternative to £85m flop Antony.
Sir Jim Ratcliffe was present at today's Manchester United ceremony paying tribute to those who lost their lives in the Munich Air Disaster 66 years ago.
Sir Alex Ferguson was also in attendence as was Erik ten Hag and other senior club officials.

Crowds are gathering at Old Trafford as we prepare to pay tribute to those who lost their lives in the Munich Air Disaster 66 years ago. Sir Alex Ferguson and Sir Jim Ratcliffe are here to pay their respects. #MUFC #ManUnited pic.twitter.com/RGXh4WQmmB
Former United chief David Gill says he approves of the incoming arrival of Omar Berrada as CEO.
He says Ineos should continue to focus on reforming the recruitment department at United so the club can enter a fresh era under Sir Jim Ratcliffe.
"I think appointing someone [Berrada] from outside is a good idea, someone with new ideas and a new perspective coming from a very successful club," Gill began.
The Ineos Group has moved a step closer to receiving regulatory approval for their 25% investment in Manchester United.
United held an emergency general meeting on Monday and a vote was held to allow the Class B shares to be transferred to Ineos chairman Sir Jim Ratcliffe.
Ratcliffe's minority bid was sanctioned by the Glazers on Christmas Eve and the Premier League are expected to ratify his £1.3billion investment in the coming weeks.
Lisandro Martinez was off the pitch the only time Ollie Watkins scored against Manchester United and the Aston Villa frontman will be spared a duel with the Argentine on Sunday.

Watkins put Villa 1-0 up at Old Trafford in the League Cup last season, running onto a threaded pass and clipping the ball over future pub quiz question answer Martin Dubravka. The defender Jacob Ramsey's curved pass evaded was Harry Maguire.
Maguire was only starting on a rotational basis as it was a domestic cup game. Martinez was back in the starting XI three days later for that week's priority: Fulham away.
Sir Jim Ratcliffe wants United to create the 'Wembley of the North' under ambitious plans for a spectacular new Old Trafford, according to a report by The Telegraph.

The INEOS chief believes the North of England should have a world-class venue to rival London's 90,000 capacity Wembley Stadium and could yet seek to lobby the UK Government for funds amid Westminster's "Levelling Up" pledges.
Today marks the 66th anniversary of the Munich Air Disaster. The annual memorial service will take place at Old Trafford this afternoon and we will be on hand with live updates and the very latest.
Former centre-back Rio Ferdinand fears the loss of Lisandro Martinez to injury risks derailing United's momentum.

The Argentine faces eight weeks on the sidelines after suffering a knee injury in Sunday's 3-0 win over West Ham United at Old Trafford. He was forced off with just under 20 minutes left and was replaced by Raphael Varane.
Ferdinand told Vibe with Five:

"He got a little injury. He's done his knee. I see he tweaked it. I think that looks like ligaments. He tried to carry on and then said, 'No, no, no I've got to go'. So, listen, if he's out, it kills it. You can see with him and Luke Shaw on that side, when they're together, they look so dominant, they look so confident, they look so compos ed with the ball. And those two are really good with the ball in terms of setting up attacks, the ball generally comes from that side."

headline: Manchester United opponents accused of doping as Gary Neville and Roy Keane make huge claim
body: Former Manchester United captains Gary Neville and Roy Keane made the allegations as they reflected on their experiences in Europe during the mid-2000s
Former Manchester United captains Gary Neville and Roy Keane have claimed players at some of the clubs they faced in the Champions League during the mid-2000s were doping.

In the '00s, United enjoyed one of their most dominant spells in history. With Sir Alex Ferguson at the helm, the Reds won the Premier League on six occasions, the League Cup three times and the FA Cup.

However, the Champions League proved elusive until 2008 when they beat Chelsea on penalties in Moscow, ending a nine-year drought since that famous comeback against Bayern Munich to lift the trophy in 1999.

United reached the last eight in seven consecutive seasons during the late 1990s and early 2000s, also making it to the semi-final in 2002 before falling to an agonising defeat to Bayer Leverkusen. Asked about the club's toughest nights in Europe, Neville recalled on the Stick to Football podcast, brought to you by Sky Bet: "There are a couple which sticks in my mind, I am going to say this for legal reasons, I think there were a few teams we played against who weren’t clean. We thought it at the time."

Agreeing, Keane added: "We played against certain teams where I would be walking off and would be absolutely shattered and I would be looking at who I have been playing against, and they looked like they hadn’t even played a match. Why can’t we talk about that?"
Neville replied: "You can’t accuse people…" To which Jamie Carragher laughed: "You just have!"
Concluding the discussion, Neville said: "My point is when you look back at what came out after in cycling and other sports with doctors, you do think. We thought it at the time.
"Physically we were fit, we weren’t drinkers [but] that’s not right, there is something not right. I came off the pitch and I thought that’s not right, that’s not right I’m sorry.
"I know that a couple of the other lads in the mid-2000s thought exactly the same thing. That is the sort of thing for me where there are no excuses."

headline: Kobbie Mainoo England call-up caution issued amid Manchester United form
body: Man United youngster Kobbie Mainoo has been touted for a place in the England squad at this forthcoming summer's European Championship.
Former Manchester United striker Dimitar Berbatov believes it's too early to suggest that Kobbie Mainoo should automatically be selected by Gareth Southgate for England's Euro 2024 squad.

The Stockport-born midfielder, 18, is being widely tipped to force his way into Southgate's plans for this summer's showpiece event in Germany. Mainoo has become a key figure in United manager Erik ten Hag's thinking in the last few months and has scored two goals in his last three matches.

His performances have been lauded by a wide audience, prompting suggestions that he could creep into Southgate's thoughts for the tournament in Germany. Southgate has a plethora of options available to him in midfield with Declan Rice and Jude Bellingham are considered as certain starters.

Many have suggested Mainoo would be the final piece in the jigsaw, offering England more energy and technical ability in the engine room. Despite his rich talent levels, Berbatov believes it is important not to get too carried away by his potential.
"It's exciting to watch players like Mainoo, especially when they have such huge talent, but one step at a time," Berbatov told Betfair. "Don't jump when you need to walk first.
"Let's not get carried away and start talking about Mainoo getting picked by Gareth Southgate and going to this summer's Euros with England.
"Obviously Ten Hag trusts Mainoo and knows how to manage him so everything else will follow in time. We need to just enjoy what's happening now and not get carried away just yet. Let Mainoo play."
Berbatov continued: "Sometimes we're too quick to judge players. For good or for bad. Just let Mainoo play and don't put too much pressure on his shoulders - he's too young for that now.

"He's doing great so we need to just let him be, let him play and let him enjoy himself. The goal he scored against Wolves was great because it shows that he's mature beyond his years. He had the courage to try something different in the last minute of the game and it was a special moment.
"Mainoo is a special player, but as with every 18-year-old, we must just let them play because at the moment, Kobbie is just enjoying football in its purest form and that's what I like to see."

headline: John Murtough is being proven right over his biggest decision at Manchester United
body: Erik ten Hag has come through a chastening five months at Man United but however bad it has been, they made the right choice.
However bad it has got at Manchester United this season, it has always been worse at Chelsea.

The Premier League was lacking a figure of fun when Ed Woodward resigned two years ago and Todd Boehly is a worthy successor. Chelsea spent more than £1billion on players over three transfer windows and are in the bottom half of the table.
For the Fulham game last month, Chelsea arranged for six identically dressed actors to stand behind the home dugout in a shameless publicity stunt to plug the new film Argylle.

"Have you seen any of those viral videos of wildly extravagant Gender Reveals where things go terribly wrong?" wrote the venerable film critic Richard Roeper. "That’s pretty much how I felt watching Argylle." The critically savaged Argylle was made for $200million, so that is another expensive dud Chelsea have damaged.
Wolves, skint and deprived of their best playing assets last season, vanquished Chelsea 4-2 on Sunday. They were unbeaten in seven games before United outclassed them for 60 minutes at Molineux.

That victory may be the turning point in United's season, for their enterprising football as much as the dramatic denouement. Wolves have done the double over Chelsea this term and beaten Manchester City and Tottenham on their own patch.

Chelsea are worse than United at almost everything bar their exquisite catering. Moises Caicedo and Enzo Fernandez almost cost a quarter of a billion between them. Caicedo was like Patrick Vieira at Brighton. Now he resembles Eric Djemba-Djemba.
Stamford Bridge is nearly half the size of Old Trafford and more dated and Thiago Silva's wife is undermining the manager.

And Mauricio Pochettino is perhaps less than the sum of his parts. Chelsea supporters barracked the players after their meek defeat at United nine weeks ago and reaching the League Cup final has not sweetened the sour mood.
Pochettino's Tottenham history will be used as a stick to beat him with eventually. More relevantly, Pochettino has been in decline for five years.

Tottenham's fortuitous and flukey run to the Champions League final in 2019 masked dismal domestic form of nine defeats between January and May. Tottenham's form was so underwhelming Ole Gunnar Solskjaer moved in permanently to the manager's office at Carrington.

Jose Mourinho replaced Pochettino at Tottenham and plenty of Chelsea supporters would welcome a repeat this week. Mourinho's name was chanted against Wolves and he still owns a London property that is two-and-a-half miles away from Stamford Bridge.

Of the three jobs Pochettino was destined to walk into after Tottenham, he opted for the most uninspiring in Paris Saint-Germain. United did not have the nerve to follow through with tentative enquiries and Real Madrid had welcomed back Zinedine Zidane.

Pochettino joined PSG after 13 months out of work. Lille pipped PSG to the post to end their Ligue 1 monopoly and though Pochettino eventually completed a clean sweep of the domestic honours, the achievements were comme ci, comme ça.

Senior members of the United dressing room preferred Pochettino to Ten Hag. His alliance with the Anglo contingent in the Southampton and Tottenham dressing rooms was viewed as a plus and he had the Premier League pedigree.

He also assembled a sterling Tottenham team: Lloris, Walker, Alderweireld, Vertonghen, Rose, Dier, Dembele, Alli, Eriksen, Son, Kane. United enquired about signing at least five of them and Sir Alex Ferguson urged Mourinho to buy Alli.

Pochettino pined for the United job. He had Ferguson's endorsement and there were at least four openings where, had United been more bullish and decisive, Pochettino would have finally walked to the home dugout at Old Trafford.

Yet come March 2022, United's favoured candidate was Ten Hag. John Murtough was nattering with Ten Hag's agent Kees Vos in the Old Trafford directors' box on Sunday and, however much longer he remains at the club, Ten Hag is his legacy. Murtough is proof there are figures at United capable of due diligence.
Pochettino and Ten Hag departed the capitals of France and the Netherlands that summer and their careers have gone in opposite directions.

During another year of waiting for Pochettino, Ten Hag presided over only the second successful season United have enjoyed since Ferguson headed upstairs in 2013. When Chelsea sacked Thomas Tuchel in September 2022, they plumped for Potter, not Pochettino.

Ten Hag has emerged from a chastening five months at United and is not out of the woods but last week was vindication. United demonstrated how clinically and efficiently they can play with their strongest players all available and they have plundered 11 goals in the last three games. They did not break double figures in the previous 10.

Watching Pochettino mutter through uninspiring press conferences, there are shades of Mourinho during his second stint at Chelsea. There were times when he looked beaten in victory on the touchline. The assumption had been if he ever returned to England it would be to United - the job he wanted.

If Pochettino had it his way, he would be sharing a glass of red with Ferguson in the directors' lounge every fortnight en route to a post-match press conference room. He would probably prefer to be at Tottenham's Enfield training base rather than Cobham.
Things are better at Tottenham and United are getting better. Chelsea are getting worse.

headline: Sir Jim Ratcliffe is responding to Manchester United wish with statement of intent
body: Manchester United co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe is reportedly wanting to create the 'Wembley of the North' as he seeks to redevelop Old Trafford
Ask match-going Manchester United fans about their priorities under Sir Jim Ratcliffe and one answer is likely to come up frequently.
For years, Old Trafford has been in desperate need of a facelift. While it remains one of the most iconic venues in world sport, it has become tired and is sadly being left behind by its competitors.

If you had said in the early '00s that Old Trafford would not be one of the venues for England, Wales, Scotland, Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland's joint Euro 2028 bid, many would have rightly laughed. However, this was the reality last year as it was overlooked in the North West by Manchester City's Etihad Stadium and Everton's new Bramley-Moore Dock development.

This snub from the FA felt like the final straw for those who had become tired of the Glazers' years of neglect. United have lost out on serious revenue because of a leaky roof, cramped conditions and an ultimately poor matchday experience.

INEOS' new investment has welcomed with it fresh hope of a rejuvenation project. In The Telegraph on Tuesday, reports emerged suggesting Ratcliffe wants to create a 'Wembley of the North' for supporters and in the process bring even more eyes to the North of England.

How Ratcliffe implements this vision is up for debate. Many would like to see the current stadium updated but the British billionaire feels fans could be receptive to a new stadium being built in the vicinity of Old Trafford.
Despite how much they oppose one another, the Glazers and supporters appear to be united on the idea of keeping Old Trafford. MEN Sport reported last March their preferences for the redevelopment.

Whatever is decided as the final plan, there is no getting away from the fact this is a statement of intent from United's new investor. A top-class stadium would be a sign of United starting to return to a powerful position once again.

Along with a potential new training ground on the horizon, United could begin to sell themselves as a new club and become an attractive proposition for some of the world's best players once again. Ratcliffe is making all the right comments, soon though it will be time for him to act.

headline: 'Why I left Manchester United and what I want to prove'
body: Isak Hansen-Aarøen left Man United on a permanent deal at the end of the January transfer window, joining Werder Bremen.
Former Manchester United youngster Isak Hansen-Aarøen has admitted his hunger for first-team football was behind his decision to leave the club in the January transfer window.

The Norwegian, 19, left United on deadline day, sealing a permanent switch to Werder Bremen. United decided they were open to selling the midfielder in the latter stages of the window after it became apparent he would not sign a new contract.

Hansen-Aarøen joined United in August 2020, following trials at the likes of Everton and Liverpool, but failed to make a single first-team appearance for the club. He was included at the start of United's pre-season campaign this season, featuring in their clashes with Leeds United and Lyon prior to the pre-season tour of the United States.

However, first-team opportunities never presented themselves for the youngster, who is understood to have become frustrated at a lack of openings. United were understood to have offered him a 'significant' new deal, but he was determined to move elsewhere in pursuit of regular game time at a senior level.

"Now for me it's about proving myself in training and showing everyone what I can do," said Hansen-Aarøen, as quoted by Sport Witness. "It was time for me to take the next step and go to a club where I could get more opportunities and show how good I am. This is definitely the step I want to take now. That was one of the reasons why I came here. I want to play men's football now and I feel ready for it."

Bremen's head of football, Clemens Fritz, has urged the youngster to improve his physicality levels and that is an ambition matched by Hansen-Aarøen. He added: "I will certainly do my workouts, but I definitely want to keep a certain pace in my game. I'm a very technical player and I hope it's fun to watch me play. I like to dribble and always give my best when I'm on the pitch."
He is still waiting to make his debut for his new club. Bremen are currently ninth in the Bundesliga table.

headline: Manchester United set for new experiment under Erik ten Hag without Lisandro Martinez
body: Just when Erik ten Hag had every senior central defender available, he is deprived of the only one certain of staying at Man United next season.
Lisandro Martinez was off the pitch the only time Ollie Watkins scored against Manchester United and the Aston Villa frontman will be spared a duel with the Argentine on Sunday.

Watkins put Villa 1-0 up at Old Trafford in the League Cup last season, running onto a threaded pass and clipping the ball over future pub quiz question answer Martin Dubravka. The defender Jacob Ramsey's curved pass evaded was Harry Maguire.
Maguire was only starting on a rotational basis as it was a domestic cup game. Martinez was back in the starting XI three days later for that week's priority: Fulham away.

That was United's final fixture before players flocked to Qatar for the World Cup. It was also the evening that the mood on the team's flight back to Manchester was sullied by the realisation that Cristiano Ronaldo had conducted an incendiary interview with Talk TV.
EXCLUSIVE: Arteta Arsenal comparison fuelling United's belief in Ten Hag

Martinez got a shout-out from Ronaldo, who named him as one of only three teammates he admired. Martinez was barely three months into his United career and was already recognised as a cult hero by those on the terraces.

He will be missed over the next eight weeks. Martinez is certain to miss seven fixtures but the tail-end of his lay-off handily coincides with the March internationals. London is calling for the centre half at Brentford on March 30 or Chelsea four days later.

In the meantime, United must cope without their only senior centre half certain of remaining at the club next season. Raphael Varane and Jonny Evans are out of contract in June, Victor Lindelof is next year and the next three months will have a big bearing on Maguire's future.
Rewatching Jarrod Bowen's one-on-one that Diogo Dalot thwarted against West Ham, there are eerie parallels with Watkins's goal. The aerial ball evades Maguire far too easily.

It was not his only lapse. He was on the back foot, rather than the front, in receiving a pass at 1-0 that Emerson Palmieri seized on. We have seen Maguire do that before (Leicester away, October 2021). The only difference was it did not lead to a goal.

Watkins enjoyed a more rhythmic Saturday night than Whigfield at Bramall Lane, scoring one and creating another two goals. Watkins has 11 goals and 10 assists in the Premier League this season and is the first Villa player to break double figures for those metrics in the top flight since Dwight Yorke in 1995-96.

Had Watkins, 28, not extended his contract with Villa by another five years in October he would be beeping on the radars of the elite clubs. Nobody will go near him now. Premier League-proven striker + England international + current top-four club = nine-figure valuation.

Watkins was on a streak of 11 goals in 14 games when Villa returned to M16 in the Premier League last April. United's back four consisted of three full-backs and one centre back but they neutered Watkins and their sheet stayed clean in a 1-0 win.

Lindelof and Luke Shaw, the defensive axis, were paired together for the third game running that afternoon. Lindelof started the last 12 games of last season in what was his finest run of form for the club while Shaw showed he is almost as good at centre back as he is at left-back.

The likelihood is it will be a completely different pairing at Villa Park. Varane was rested against West Ham as, in the words of one high-profile United source, "Varane has said, 'I can't do this any more.'" That would be starting twice in a week.

Maguire's two near-costly errors blemished an otherwise accomplished return on his first start in nearly nine weeks at the weekend. It is easy to forget that when he clutched his groin against Bayern Munich and limped off, he was serenaded by United supporters. Maguire has shown commendable resilience and was the Premier League Player of the Month for November.

Starting Maguire and Varane would be another contradiction, though. Erik ten Hag effectively said earlier this season they were competing for the same right-sided slot at centre half. Lindelof was bracketed among the defenders adept on the left.

Lindelof also recently returned from a long lay-off of 10 weeks, having undergone groin surgery in December. Evans was in the directors' box rather than the dugout against West Ham, pushed back down the pecking order after a prominent period.

Maguire and Varane have started a mere three games together under Ten Hag - all of them this season - and none of them were in the league. United have form for mollifying Watkins, though. And without Martinez.

headline: Manchester United remember Munich air disaster with poignant ceremony
body: It was the 66th anniversary of the tragic Munich air disaster on Tuesday and a ceremony took place at Old Trafford.
Sir Jim Ratcliffe and Sir Alex Ferguson stoically walked alongside each other beneath the Munich memorial plaque to warm applause from hundreds of Manchester United fans.

The rain did not relent throughout Tuesday in Manchester but that didn't stop supporters from gathering to pay their respects to those who tragically lost their lives in the Munich air disaster. On the 6th of February 1958, 23 people lost their lives in one of the darkest days in the club's history.

They will never be forgotten and this year's ceremony to mark the disaster's 66th anniversary made for a moving afternoon in difficult weather conditions. Reverend John Boyers, the former United club chaplain, led proceedings in a typically dignified fashion and a rendition of The Flowers of Manchester raised hairs on the skin of attendees.

Eight players, three members of club staff, eight journalists and four other crew members suffered fatal injuries in Munich, sending Manchester and the football world into mourning. More than half a century since the disaster and their spirit lives on. Tuesday's ceremony was a touching tribute and a reminder of how cruelly those lives were taken in the snow.

Ratcliffe, Ferguson, Dave Brailsford and Andy Burnham stood together throughout the ceremony, while Erik ten Hag, Bruno Fernandes, Marc Skinner and Katie Zelem stood a few yards away. There were youngsters from the academy in attendance and a member of the Under-13 team bravely read a poem. "I wasn't alive when the Busy Babes played, I wasn't alive when they went to Belgrade, I only know stories that have been told, memories that have grown old," it read.
"A group of boys with passion and skill, with pace and courage, who would attack teams with will. Byrne, Jones, Edwards, Taylor, Coleman, Whelan, Pegg and Bent. They played like heaven-sent.
"It shouldn't have happened and we ask ourselves why, but their team spirit will never die. No matter what colour, blue or red, on February 6th we remember the dead."

Kady Cavannagh and Steve Douglas shared poems and the emphasis on the yearly ceremony being fan-led has not been lost. Munich58 was created in 2001 to ensure the memory of those who lost their lives continued and more fans seem to attend the ceremony each year.

Another emotive rendition of The Flowers of Manchester from Pete Martin followed and a chorus of 'we'll never die, we'll never die' broke out after the performance. There was a visible mix of young and old supporters gathered to pay their respects. It is essential for any young United fan to be educated about the Munich air disaster.

Jimmy Murphy's son, Paddy Crerand, Brian Kidd and John Murtough were among the other notable attendees. As Sir Matt Busby fought for his life in hospital after the disaster, Murphy became caretaker manager and promised that United would rebuild and enjoy a prosperous future.

"The Red Devils will rise again" Murphy said just days after the crash. "It took Matt Busby, Bert Whalley and myself 13 years to produce the 1958 Red Devils. It was long, tiring, hard work. But we succeeded. We reached a perfect system. We had the best set-up in football.“It will again be a long, tiring job to rebuild the Red Devils. This time, we have to start practically from scratch. But we'll do it."

Murphy was right and United did rebuild. Sir Bobby Charlton was at the centre of that and following his passing in October, this year’s anniversary was the first without any living disaster survivors. Charlton miraculously survived the crash and carried that trauma his entire life. Rev Boyers touched on Charlton's passing and a tribute to others who passed in the last year was paid.
That included Lady Cathy Ferguson, the wife of Sir Alex, who passed away last year. The crowd broke into applause and Ferguson solemnly bowed his head and uttered 'thank you'.

Ferguson and Ratcliffe exchanged words at the end of the ceremony. Ratcliffe was born in Failsworth, grew up supporting United and was six years old when the Munich disaster happened. It was a classy touch for Ratcliffe to attend and representation at the ceremony from INEOS will not go unnoticed by fans, who have become accustomed to absent custodians.
The flowers of English football, the flowers of Manchester. They will not be forgotten.

headline: Manchester United player's comeback overshadowed by fan's 'obscene act' on teammate
body: Sevilla have called for LaLiga to take "appropriate measures" after Lucas Ocampos appeared to be touched in an "obscene act" by a Rayo Vallecano fan during Monday's match
Hannibal Mejbri's return to the Sevilla side was overshadowed after a fan behaved inappropriately towards his teammate Lucas Ocampos during a match against Rayo Vallecano.

Sevilla have conveyed their "disgust" at the incident and the club is calling for LaLiga to take action. Hannibal was making his first appearance for new side after their bizarre decision to make him unavailable for first-team selection.

The Tunisia international, who spent last season on loan at Birmingham City in the Championship, signed for Sevilla in January in an initial loan deal after playing 10 matches for United in the first half of the campaign. Sevilla manager Quique Sanchez Flores opted to overlook the midfielder for selection for a recent Copa del Rey clash with Atletico Madrid, saying: "we are going to give him the necessary space to understand where he is, that he is at Sevilla and what it means."
EXCLUSIVE: Arteta Arsenal comparison fuelling United's belief in Ten Hag

Hannibal returned to the matchday squad against Osasuna on January 28 after president Jose Maria del Nido Carrasco said the decision was "blown out of proportion" but he did not come off the bench. The 21-year-old made his comeback by playing the final eight minutes of their 2-1 away win over Rayo, in which the incident with Ocampos happened.

Argentina international Ocampos was poked by a fan while preparing to take a throw-in during the game. Sevilla have released a statement supporting their player and asking LaLiga to respond appropriately.

LaLiga has confirmed that the police have identified the young fan involved and will report the incident to the public prosecutor's office for minors due to his age. Sevilla's official website posted a statement: "On the obscene and completely inappropriate act suffered by Lucas Ocampos at the Estadio de Vallecas:

"We would like to place on record our disgust at the incident that occurred on Monday during our match against Rayo Vallecano, in which our player Lucas Ocampos was subjected to an obscene and completely inappropriate act by a home fan.

"We hope that the appropriate measures outlined in the regulations will be taken to prevent such behaviour from happening again on a football field and we have expressed this to LaLiga directly. These gestures and behaviours should not be allowed in our competition if we aspire to be the best league in the world."

"We send our full support to Lucas Ocampos, who showed composure and immense professionalism, despite the unacceptable behaviour of the fan who harassed him." After his side's victory, Ocampos addressed the incident with DAZN: "I hope the league takes it seriously, like it takes racism, like it takes those things.

"I don't think all the Rayo people are like that, because the truth is that they always treat us with respect. There is always a fool and I hope it doesn't happen in other areas, because if it happens in women's football, we know what can happen."

"I restrained myself because I have two daughters and I hope that tomorrow it doesn't happen to them. Let's hope they make the decision they have to make and I hope that a fool like this doesn't stain the fans, because the truth is they behaved very well."
LaLiga responded to the incident in a statement: "LaLiga is going to report the incident to the Public Prosecutor's Office for minors as it involves a minor. The police have already identified him."

Rayo also released a statement, condemning the behaviour of the fan. The club said: "This isolated action is solely the individual responsibility of the fan who carried it out, with neither Rayo Vallecano nor any of the other almost 15,000 spectators who filled the Estadio de Vallecas for the match against Sevilla having any responsibility for it and who had exemplary behaviour.
"Rayo Vallecano at this time is working to identify the fan so that, if he is a season ticket holder, it can adopt the appropriate disciplinary measures according to the internal regulations.
"Rayo Vallecano has always promoted the maximum respect towards referees, footballers and coaches. Individual actions like this are opposite to the values that Rayo Vallecano promotes."

headline: Lisandro Martinez injury blow raises an uncomfortable question for Manchester United
body: Man Utd will be without their best defender for the third time since he joined the club in the summer of 2022.
The fact so many rival fans appear to be revelling in Lisandro Martinez's latest injury setback shows just how feared he is.
Without him, Manchester United are an inferior side, and of all the players they have had to cope without this season, he is the one they have missed the most.

Martinez did not steal the show in any of the four games he played after making his brief return from injury, yet in all of them he still shone in an understated way, passing the ball with ease and opening up other avenues of attack that were often overlooked.
United's latest setback is a huge blow to their slim hopes of Champions League qualification and further bad luck for Erik ten Hag in a season when he has had to constantly adapt his team selections.
MOST READ: Greenwood responds to Bellingham incident after loanee backed

It is also a reminder of the balancing act Ten Hag treads. His own hopes of success rely on Martinez, but he is slowly becoming a player who cannot be relied upon all the time. For all of his unquestionable talent, the best ability is availability. Martinez hasn't been known for that during his time at Old Trafford.

The Argentina international has missed 34 matches across two serious injury setbacks, and it could be around 42 by the time he is next back in action. It means he has already been injured for 35.78% of matches since he joined the club, and it will stand at 40.77% if he misses the next eight matches as well.

Martinez is not injury-prone in the traditional sense of a player who breaks down a lot, but is injury-prone as a byproduct of his gladiatorial style of play. He plays with his heart on his sleeve and the pride of his family flowing through his veins, an ice-cold conviction countered by a heated passion to give everything he has for the greater good of the team.

It is that tenacity that makes Martinez the fan favourite he is, yet it leaves him so susceptible to the type of injury he suffered against West Ham. If you take those chaotic confrontations out of his game, he probably suffers fewer injuries, but his game would also suffer.

'The Butcher' needs an edge. He needs a 90-minute nemesis, someone who can incite the volatile side of him and bring him as close to the mark as possible. It is in those murky channels that he plays his best, yet at the same time he is so close to overstepping the line as well.

Martinez's absence is also another tactical blow for a United side that has lacked identity all season. Ten Hag is a firm believer in having a left-footed centre-back whenever possible because it allows them to receive the ball easier and offer up a host of different passing angles, both of which are crucial to building from the back.

''Because the left-footed are better orientated on the left side, in possession you then have better angles," he said during his first summer at the club. "But out of possession also the orientation is better and the angles are more comfortable to cut out and cover for a full-back.''
It is this reasoning that means Jonny Evans, Luke Shaw, and Victor Lindelof could all be likelier replacements for Martinez than Harry Maguire, given the better balance it will provide the backline.

At the same time, it only further highlights the importance of Martinez to this United side and the tricky task Ten Hag faces of utilising him to his full potential while also trying to smooth those rough edges.
When he is fit, Martinez is United's best defender. It means he isn't anymore.

headline: Manchester United's surprise package of the season is needed to perform again
body: Man United defender Lisandro Martinez sustained an injury in the 3-0 win against West Ham, just weeks after his return.
"I'm not a person who struggles with pressure, mentally,” said Harry Maguire in September.

“I have been through a lot in the last couple of years and I have been Manchester United captain for nearly four years. You take a huge lot of responsibility and everything that comes with it and that is a lot of bad as well as good. But it was a huge honour.”
That post-match interview with Maguire came after an England victory at Hampden Park, a game in which the defender was targeted by Scotland fans throughout the 90 minutes.
Maguire was ridiculed whenever he got the ball. Gareth Southgate was seething and said, “I have never known a player to be treated in this way," when speaking to the press.
The defender was stripped of the captaincy by Erik ten Hag last summer and he remained down the pecking order at United when playing that game for England.
However, just a few weeks later, he started his first game of the Premier League season against Brentford and assisted the match-winning goal, which was the start of his renaissance.
Maguire started the next 13 games in all competitions and that run was only brought to an end when he sustained an injury against Bayern Munich in the Champions League.
His redemption arc gathered pace in October when he scored against FC Copenhagen at Old Trafford, a crucial contribution which gave United hope of progressing from the group.
The 30-year-old has enjoyed a strong campaign and he's no longer the butt of jokes for opposition fans. His resilience has been impressive and he deserves immense praise for his attitude.
West Ham were interested in signing Maguire but the move didn't materialise and it seemed unlikely he would regain the trust of Ten Hag after becoming the fifth choice in his position.
Maguire made just eight league starts last season and he was demoralised by a natural left-back, Luke Shaw, being selected over him in the centre of defence on various occasions.
Nobody expected Maguire to rise up the pecking order again, but his consistent performances combined with injuries to Lisandro Martinez and Raphael Varane have seen that happen.
Maguire was absent himself during the festive period after picking up a groin injury, but he's now fit again and he started in the 3-0 victory over West Ham.
Although there were a few shaky moments on his return to action, Maguire delivered another decent display and he will be needed in the coming weeks, especially after Martinez's injury.
Martinez has sustained an injury to the medial collateral ligament in his knee and is set to be sidelined for at least two months. That is a huge blow but it could have been worse.
The worst possible outcome was feared for Martinez, who had only just returned from a lay-off, when he went to the ground with a knee injury in the second half on Sunday afternoon.
Martinez is key to how Ten Hag wants to play and his ability to pass through the lines is invaluable. His absence will be felt, so his teammates must step up while he recovers again.
Last season, Maguire coming into the team would have been a cause for concern, but he's put a torrid few years behind him to play his best football since working under Ole Gunnar Solskjaer.
It's fair to say Maguire could be considered the surprise package of the campaign, given his limited involvement last term, the stripping of his captaincy and that he was expected to leave.
Nobody expected a renaissance and the player's mental strength has been the reason for that. Maguire might have the last laugh yet.

headline: Alejandro Garnacho's last six Manchester United goals show he is becoming a complete winger
body: Erik ten Hag had called for consistency from Alejandro Garnacho and the Man Utd teenager is starting to deliver just that.

For every young footballer, there is a moment when the penny drops. A game or an action when the path to greatness can become just that little clearer. Sometimes it's a setback, often it's an act that can show them just how much potential is contained within.

With Alejandro Garnacho, that moment is increasingly looking like the third minute of Manchester United's 3-0 win at Everton in November. That spectacular overhead kick to silence a seething Goodison Park should already have wrapped up the goal of the season award and for the Argentine, it has kickstarted his most productive spell in a United shirt.

That goal was the first of six, along with two assists, that Garnacho has delivered in his last 15 games. That's a reasonable return but most importantly it's an improving one as well. The teenager is beginning to influence games to a greater degree this season and he doesn't turn 20 until July.

Garnacho is now on a run of 19 successive starts dating back to November 1, which is a remarkable statistic when you consider that before then he had only ever begun two successive matches for United. For a long time, he was a super sub, a player capable of making an impact off the bench but who was strangely subdued when he started. No longer.

Until that goal at Everton, four of Garnacho's six for United had come as a sub and all four of his assists had been as a replacement. A year ago Ten Hag was calling for more goals and more assists and the winger was someone who if he did start tended to be replaced.

Before he started this run of 19 games in a row, he had completed 90 minutes just twice for United, against Charlton Athletic and Crystal Palace in the Carabao Cup. Five times in this streak of games he has now completed 90 minutes, but in 12 of them he has made it until the 84th minute at least.

This is a sign of a player starting to deliver more regularly. The game after his Everton wonder goal he scored at Galatasaray. He struck twice in a scintillating performance against Aston Villa and then twice more against West Ham on Sunday. What was particularly telling about his impact at the weekend was that he didn't play particularly well in the first half. When that has happened previously he has drifted out of games, but now he has the belief and the confidence to keep going and put it behind him.

After that stunner on Merseyside there were inevitable comparisons with Wayne Rooney and Cristiano Ronaldo, the last two teenage sensations to make an impact at United. Ten Hag refused to get involved too heavily in that discussion but did point out where Garnacho could improve.
“Don’t compare, I don’t think it is right,” he said. “They all have their own identity but for Garnacho to go that way he has a lot to come, he has to work very hard.

"You have to do it on a consistent basis and so far he has not. But he definitely has high potential to do some amazing things. It's not the first time we saw this, we have already often seen glimpses but if you want to be a player like Rooney or Ronaldo you have to score 20 [or] 25 goals in the Premier League each season.
"That's not easy to get, you have to work hard, you have to go in areas where it hurts. So [there is] a lot to come. But potential, he has."

Twenty goals will be beyond him this season, but the consistency is coming into his game. He has earned his run in the team and appears undroppable now. What is particularly telling is the way he has adapted to a right-wing role, having been used almost exclusively on the left until his superb Boxing Day performance against Villa. In November 2022, Garnacho expressed his preference for that left-wing role and explained why he wanted to play there.

“I’ve always liked to play out wide on the left, as a right-footed player able to cut inside,” he told club media. “To be able to play as a right-footed player down the left, you also have to be pretty decent with your weaker foot.
"From an early age, I’ve always practiced hard using both feet, because that makes you into a much better player and so nowadays I can play with both feet – not to perfection but to a good standard."

That practice is paying off now. His doubles against Villa and West Ham included a goal with either foot and his strike in Istanbul was with his left foot. So of those six goals, half were with his right and half with his left.

There's no doubt Garnacho is now part of United's best front three, keeping £85million winger Antony out of the team. There is still more to come from the 19-year-old, but it does feel like his wonder strike back in November might have been a turning point in his fledgling career.

headline: Donny van de Beek's nightmare won't end after leaving Manchester United on loan
body: Donny van de Beek signed for Eintracht Frankfurt on loan with a view to a permanent move in the January transfer window.
Donny van de Beek was an unused substitute for Eintracht Frankfurt on Saturday as his side stumbled to a 2-0 defeat against relegation-threatened FC Koln.

Eintracht have the option to buy Van de Beek for €11million (£9.55m), with €3m (£2.6m) in add-ons, so it was possible that he'd played his last game for Manchester United, but his underwhelming start in Germany suggests a permeant deal might not materialise.
Van de Beek started his first two games for Eintracht and was hooked at half-time in his third appearance. He subsequently lost his starting role against Koln.
If that wasn't bad enough, it emerged on Monday afternoon that Van de Beek had been omitted from Eintracht's squad for their Europa League Conference campaign.
UEFA regulations state clubs are only able to make three changes to their 25-man squads for European competition and Van de Beek has missed out.
Eintracht's other January signings, Sasa Kalajdzic, Hugo Ekitike and Philipp Max, have taken up those places instead, which is another huge blow for a player whose career has tailed off.
"If you don't play as many games as you want, it's tough, but that's the past now. I'm here now and I'm positive, which is the most important thing," Van de Beek when he signed on loan.

"I'm looking forward now. I think it helps when you play with players [at United] who have achieved a lot and have experience. You see them in training every day, which helps develop you and I'll try to bring that here as well to help the team.

"I've seen a lot in football now and hope to be able to pass on some of it on here. If the coach puts me on the field, I'll of course be ready. I'm fit, I played a few friendlies in the training ground. I know that's different, but I trained hard in Manchester.
"I feel good. Of course, you also need match practice to get to your best level, but I'm fit and this is the most important thing."
Van de Beek described his time in Manchester as 'tough', but it looks like there is no respite in Frankfurt and being snubbed from their Conference League squad represents a new low.

“He has had many injuries, first of all,” Ten Hag recently said about Van de Beek. "From the first moment I came in here at Manchester United, he wasn’t the player he was at Ajax because he was injured. So many times he was not available and then he struggled for a long time to recover from that injury.

“That is probably the main reason why he was not playing. We decided for a loan in the summer but it didn’t come and then his opportunities are few because also we make appointments and we make agreements with players and contract players in that position. The competition was high.”
Ten Hag blamed injuries for Van de Beek's regression, but he was available for the entirety of United's pre-season in 2022 and named on the bench in the Dutchman's first four fixtures.
The bottom line is Van de Beek was not good enough for United and although it was thought German football would suit him, he might have to accept another drop in level.
Remarkably, Van de Beek was a Ballon d'Or nominee in 2019 after his influential role in Ajax's domestic double triumph and progression to the Champions League semi-finals.
Unfortunately, his career has nosedived since and his decline shows no signs of relenting.

headline: Why Erik ten Hag is in a more secure position than previous Manchester United managers
body: Man United have a fine record in Saturday 12.30pm kick-offs under Erik ten Hag but West Ham away proves to be one of the toughest.
Of the Manchester United starting XI at West Ham in May, five at the very most will walk out for the Premier League anthem at the London Stadium on Saturday.
Aaron Wan-Bissaka's recall is enforced by Diogo Dalot's suspension but Marcus Rashford cannot be certain of a return. Captain Bruno Fernandes can.

The misfiring Antony is not assured of keeping his place and Christian Eriksen, back in team training this week, will likely be on the bench. Luke Shaw was in the midst of an accomplished run at centre half and Victor Lindelof was an ever-present. Tyrell Malacia has made one start since and required two rounds of surgery on his knee while Casemiro's absence with a hamstring problem is 51 days and counting.
Of the starters seven months ago, only David de Gea and Wout Weghorst have permanently left but the lack of continuity partly accounts for United's erratic form in Erik ten Hag's second season.
De Gea's flimsy attempt to repel Said Benrahma's back-pass of a shot was one of the last nails in his coffin. Ilkay Gundogan hammered in the last at Wembley a month later.
As costly as De Gea's successor, Andre Onana, has been in the Champions League, there are bigger problems up the other end. United have not scored in three games.

That last happened more recently than some may think - February and March 2021 during a stultifying streak of three goalless draws. Failure to score at West Ham would see another post-Ferguson record tumble: United have never gone four games without a goal since the Scot headed upstairs to the Old Trafford directors' box.

There are uncomfortable parallels between Ten Hag's second season and Louis van Gaal's. United have four goals fewer than they did after 17 Premier League games in that soporific 2015-16 campaign, three more defeats and a point fewer.

Only one of United's nine wins has been by more than a one-goal margin and the 3-0 defeat of Everton looks an anomaly. United were uncharacteristically clinical that day with three goals from four attempts on target: a wonder goal, a penalty and a counter-attack.

The difference between the Dutch managers is there were growing calls for Van Gaal to go during his winter of discontent. United did not win a single game out of eight in December, lost four in succession and went out at the Champions League group stage.

The tight turnaround post-Christmas of a game on Boxing Day at Stoke and against Chelsea on December 28 essentially reprieved Van Gaal. United were spirited and enterprising in a goalless draw with champions Chelsea, hitting the woodwork twice on a night United-themed Jose Mourinho scarves were sold on the Old Trafford forecourt amid the possibility of a mid-season approach.

Ten Hag does not face a similar threat. The Ineos Group's minority stake has still not been ratified at the time of writing and the sole kingmaker at a club with an interim chief executive and a football director on borrowed time is the absentee landlord Joel Glazer.

There is not an obvious and available upgrade as there was with Mourinho. The majority of United supporters would rather have Ten Hag over Graham Potter, a fine coach who oversaw magnificent progress with Brighton, but is more suited to succeeding Gareth Southgate as England manager after the European Championship.
Potter is only at the top of bookies' chalkboards as he is free. He is followed by Zinedine Zidane and Julen Lopetegui, also both out of work. Antonio Conte and Hansi Flick are also up there.

Fan power contributed to Van Gaal's downfall as thousands of season-ticket holders threatened not to renew if he remained for a third term. Ten Hag does not face a similar threat and authority to the United manager's role was restored with his appointment. Removing him would empower the minority of players looking to wait it out. The specific booing of a gaggle of players against Bournemouth was significant.

United bowed to player power by sacking Mourinho a week before Christmas in 2018. Van Gaal's methods irked several players who continued to undermine him days before the FA Cup final but the spectre of Mourinho was ample motivation not to down tools. There was also the glory of the FA Cup to play for.

Half-term reports are due after Boxing Day and it is already an unflattering look for United to have lost more games than they have won. United have a variable record at the London Stadium of three wins, three defeats and one draw. Ed Woodward later admitted the loss under Mourinho was one of the most difficult defeats he endured in September 2018.
That was also a Saturday 12.30pm kick-off.

headline: Manchester United outcast Jadon Sancho should listen to Raphael Varane's honest advice
body: Jadon Sancho's time at Man United is coming to an end after his public disagreement with manager Erik ten Hag.
There have been more recent photos of Jadon Sancho at social events than of him playing football.

Sancho has not played since August 26 and he's been on an individual training plan since falling out with Erik ten Hag, who responded to his extraordinary outburst on social media by banishing him from the squad. It's been a great shame to see a chapter of his career - the world was once at his feet - wasted over something that should have been quickly quashed, but it would be foolish to underestimate egos in football.
Although Sancho is remarkably the last United forward to have scored a home Premier League goal, he hasn't been missed and he's expected to leave in the January transfer window.

"It is about a culture and every player has to match certain standards," said Ten Hag two weeks ago. "What will happen there, he knows what he has to do if he wants to return and it is up to him. We will see what will happen."
