Sancho has, rather crucially, still not apologised and that's why the stalemate with his manager has rumbled on into the winter. The player strongly believes he's not done anything wrong and he's refused to back down.

Whoever Sancho is taking advice from clearly isn't qualified to provide him with counsel. His stubbornness has cost him months of his career and it wouldn't have taken much to apologise without meaning it.

Sancho is known to be a pleasant and likeable person, from regularly engaging with fans to opening a pitch for kids where he grew up. However, there seems to be a lack of discipline in his life and Nemanja Matic recently said he was regularly late to training. There have also been timekeeping issues when he's represented England and Borussia Dortmund.

Sancho needs to address that to progress in his career, but an apology is all he needs to make right now. Yet it's clear that's not going to happen and that his ego is standing in the way of a resolution. Interestingly, Raphael Varane this week discussed the challenge of becoming an elite player in a lengthy post on LinkedIn - where he doesn't post often - and he spoke of the importance of controlling ego.

He wrote: "As someone who has played international and Champions League football, I feel extremely lucky to have done so. I also know what is required to get here. A critical element of reaching the top level is making the right decisions for yourself.

"Many of these decisions stem from ego, something that for me is one of the most important things to keep control of, and can give you a better mentality when used correctly. In football and in life, I have found that, as long as you have a strong mindset and continue to act on it, you can reach new heights.

"The accolades and recognition you get are a consequence of the decisions you make. If you focus on the process and enjoy the small improvements rather than only focusing on the result, you can always achieve great things."

It would be wrong to suggest a post from Varane was a subliminal message to Sancho but sometimes the shoe fits and it's the type of advice he should be listening to instead of refusing to apologise. Furthermore, Varane is well-placed to give such advice after falling out of favour with Ten Hag himself and seeing Jonny Evans start over him.
Varane has started the last two games against Bayern Munich and Liverpool and it would be bizarre to see him moved back to the bench in the coming weeks considering his performance at Anfield.
The Frenchman has shown Sancho how to react.

headline: I was shocked by what Manchester United did against Liverpool FC
body: Man Utd showed character to hold on and get a good point away at Anfield in the Premier League on Sunday afternoon.
If you can't win a game, then it is imperative that you don't lose. The biggest compliment you pay Manchester United is that they actually did that yesterday.

Liverpool's 7-0 thrashing earlier in the year was still very much fresh in the memory and much of the talk ahead of the match was about how many the home side would win by rather than if they would at all.

United have been hammered for the pathetic nature of some of their defeats this season, particularly against Newcastle and Bournemouth in recent weeks, and the lack of character shown on such occasions, but this time they just did enough.
This is a United side that is still relying on moments to have any joy against the very best sides and in the biggest moments at Anfield, they somehow found a way for them to turn their way.

United have been guilty of overcomplicating things under Ten Hag and trying to run before they can walk, but this was a case of keeping things simple so that they had the foundations in place to possibly nick a positive result.

It was always going to rely on a little bit of luck at the back to withstand the Liverpool bombardment and a bit of brilliance in attack for United to make the most of their infrequent forays into the opposition half. They worked for their luck, but once again their lack of experience in the forward line was glaring.

Liverpool were always going to be on top, so there was little surprise to see United adopt a defensive approach to counter it. Yet, no matter how ugly and unorthodox it was at times, they stubbornly survived with a show of real willingness and determination.

United were never going to beat Jurgen Klopp's side at their own game but they would always stand a chance if they dug deep, frustrated the home side and played the seasonal role of pantomime villains.

Andre Onana hesitated over every goalkick until the last possible nanosecond and Antony riled the home crowd with his fiery contest against Konstantinos Tsimikas. Just as important, though, was the experience of Raphael Varane and Jonny Evans at the heart of the United defence. They are the ninth different centre-back pairing used already this season, and between them, they have seen it all.

They dug deep with their defensive work and organised backline. They used every trick in the book to ruin the rhythm of the match and disrupt Liverpool from bombarding the goal in the same manner they had started the match.

But even on the rare occasions United penetrated the Liverpool backline, they lacked the composure and clinical finishing required to make the home side pay. Alejandro Garnacho took a poor touch, Rasmus Hojlund fired at Alisson Becker and Scott McTominay launched a speculative shot well wide of goal.
On another day, one of those chances might have gone in and they would have won the game. Liverpool could say exactly the same about the opportunities they somehow squandered.

That in itself is the ultimate compliment you can pay this United team. It wasn't a memorable match, but it was a memorable performance for the way they dug deep and almost nicked the match themselves.

So perhaps a draw was a fair result. Liverpool dominated but there were plenty of false dawns and for all the pressure they applied to the United goal, they still struggled to carve out any clear-cut chances to score.
It is a credit to United that Liverpool fans were the ones leaving Anfield annoyed. Now that is a shock.

headline: Eight of Erik ten Hag's 11 Manchester United signings are fighting for their places
body: Man Utd produced their best performance of the season in beating Everton with a team that looked familiar to previous eras.

It was Manchester United's best away win under Erik ten Hag but came with a heavy dose of nostalgia. Squint a little and there was more than the faint outline of an Ole Gunnar Solskjaer team in action in red at Goodison Park.

There were Victor Lindelof and Harry Maguire propelling everything thrown at them at centre-back. Scott McTominay was holding the midfield together and Marcus Rashford and Antony Martial combined in attack. There was a new man in the dugout and a new goalkeeper, but plenty of familiarity aside from that.

To give credit to Ten Hag, he has overseen the development and promotion of Kobbie Mainoo and taken Alejandro Garnacho to the next level, but his stamp on the team has become less evident as he has gone back to basics this season. After a shaky start to the season, that approach has worked with five wins out of six in the Premier League.

The 3-0 win at Everton on Sunday was the best win of the season, as well as the first statement away win of the Ten Hag era, but it came without a single Ten Hag signing starting outfield, although Andre Onana was excellent in goal. This might be close to United's best team at the moment, but it almost certainly isn't the team that their manager wants to pick.

Both Harry Maguire and Scott McTominay could have left this summer, while Mason Mount was supposed to be the final piece of the jigsaw in midfield. Ten Hag wanted his team to become more dominant in their play, but it unravelled early in the season and although injuries haven't helped, he has been forced to retreat from that ideal to get results on the board.

The question now is how he goes back to moving the team on. The win at Everton was gritty and determined, but you could argue it wasn't a team playing in the image of its manager, although injuries remain a major issue for Ten Hag.

When everyone is fit again, he might look to restore some of his signings to the team, but right now it's arguable only two more would get in alongside Onana, who after a nervous spell in goal is beginning to look like a very good signing.

If we include Sofyan Amrabat, on whom United have an option to make the move permanent, Ten Hag has signed 11 players across his three transfer windows, at a cost of more than £400million. Some were signed to play bit-part roles, such as backup goalkeeper Altay Bayindir and free agent Jonny Evans.

Maybe the same could be said for Tyrell Malacia, who is on the comeback trail after a serious knee injury, but there was an expectation he would challenge the excellent Luke Shaw and that hasn't happened. Shaw is comfortably the better player.

In the centre of defence, Lisandro Martinez would get back in this team, ahead of Lindelof and alongside Maguire, but the picture in midfield is complicated. Bruno Fernandes is undroppable and Mainoo's outstanding performance at Everton has put him in the frame for more appearances, with Scott McTominay now starting seven of the last eight games in all competitions, only missing the Carabao Cup defeat to Newcastle.

McTominay and Mainoo are starting ahead of Amrabat at the moment, with the Fiorentina loanee failing to make an impression on the team so far. Christian Eriksen had been showing some form of late, but Mount has had a difficult start to life at Old Trafford and his route back into the team looks complicated given the emergence of Mainoo.

In attack, Rasmus Hojlund will return to take the place of Martial, despite the latter's goal at Goodison Park, but Antony will surely remain on the periphery even when fit. The £85million winger has never looked like living up to that price tag and his influence on games has been minimal this season.

Ten Hag said a couple of weeks ago that Rashford would stay in the team despite his struggles for form, so having finally netted his second goal of the season his place is secure. Garnacho has also been playing well of late and after his majestic overhead kick on Sunday, there is no way he can be dropped at the moment.

So at the moment, if everyone was fit, it might only be Martinez and Hojlund that join Onana in that team. If Bayindir and Evans were signed to be reserves and you can make a case that Malacia and Eriksen were also deals to add strength to the team, it still leaves Casemiro, Mount, Amrabat and Antony on the outside.
The majority of these players would be in the team that Ten Hag wants to build at United. But for now, the approach to getting results might be leaving some of them out of favour.

headline: Sir Dave Brailsford meeting former Manchester United staff as 'brutal' changes planned
body: Changes are planned at Man United as Ineos prepare to assume control of the football operations at the club.
Sir Dave Brailsford is sounding out former staff at Manchester United as the Ineos Group prepares to make sweeping changes at the club.
Brailsford, the Ineos sporting director, is conducting thorough due diligence and a source has suggested the changes at United could be "brutal".
United sources say Brailsford has been attending meetings this month to gauge the performance challenge at United, whose title drought is certain to tick past 12 years.
Although Ineos plan to hire a sporting director and potentially a head of recruitment, the incumbent football director John Murtough wants to remain at the club.
A club source said in December it was "in the balance" as to whether Murtough stays at United or ends his decade-long association with the club.
The Manchester Evening News revealed last month Ineos are open to retaining Murtough in a more administrative role and Murtough never envisaged his role at United to centre on recruitment.

United have backed manager Erik ten Hag with investment of more than £400million on signings and sources have stressed they were tracking certain targets before the Dutchman was appointed in April 2022.
However, Murtough feels his involvement in picking players has been limited and six of Ten Hag's permanent additions played in the Eredivisie.

Brailsford and Jean Claude Blanc, the Ineos chief executive for sport, are due to join the United football board. A new chief executive could report into Blanc but it is unlikely Patrick Stewart, the interim chief executive, will stay in the role permanently.
Blanc and Brailsford accompanied Sir Jim Ratcliffe at meetings with United fan groups on Monday.

headline: Jack Fletcher is still ahead of father Darren in his development at Manchester United despite Youth Cup agony
body: Jack Fletcher and Tyler Fletcher have appeared in the FA Youth Cup and Uefa Youth League for Man United already this season and are only still 16.
"When they're on the pitch, we don't know which is which" was a chant incepted for the Da Silva twins and it could soon be allocated to the Fletchers.

Tyler and Jack were regulars in the Old Trafford directors' box last season while still in the Manchester City academy and in attendance on derby day. Amid the bedlam over Bruno Fernandes' equaliser and Marcus Rashford's winner, nobody clocked whether the teenagers dared to celebrate.

The 16-year-olds' allegiance will almost certainly have been with their father, Darren. The United technical director has to walk past the front row of journalists in the press box to take his seat with the United analysts towards the back of the Sir Bobby Charlton Stand. Occasionally, he will wave at his sons and wife Hayley.

The Fletcher twins' devotion to the red side of Manchester was confirmed when they crossed the divide to join United's academy in the summer for a combined fee of £1.25million. Should they emulate their father, they would become the 13th set of brothers to play for the United first team.

Jack and Tyler were born on the same day Cristiano Ronaldo settled an FA Cup quarter-final replay with Middlesbrough in March 2007. Darren was present for their birth as he was recovering from an ankle injury.

It was barely seven years ago that nine-year-old Jack and Tyler Fletcher were having a kickabout on the Hawthorns pitch with Kai Rooney eight days before Christmas. Darren was halfway through his final season at West Brom and soon started heading up the M6 and towards home in Manchester, spending two years with Stoke City.

Fletcher attended meetings at Old Trafford towards the end of his playing career with the intention of joining United's new structure. His return was formally confirmed in January 2021 as a first-team coach and two months later he was appointed the technical director.

If Erik ten Hag needs numbers in training on a recovery day for senior players, he or assistant Mitchell van der Gaag will consult Fletcher, who has become a conduit between the academy and the first team. Fletcher first encountered a hirsute Van der Gaag when he collected stickers for his Scottish Premiership album in the mid-90s. Van der Gaag spent two years at Motherwell.

Jack Fletcher first got the call to head across from the academy building, past the 'fountain of youth' and into the main team hub at Carrington in November. He has trained a handful of times with the first team while Tyler has started twice for the youth team.

It is worth reminding the Fletchers do not turn 17 until March 19. The Manchester-born brothers have played for England and Scotland at youth level and Tyler has pledged his allegiance to Scotland while Jack has chosen to represent England.

Tyler made his international debut for Scotland in September 2022, then played for England two months later, defected back to Scotland last February before playing with Jack for England in their triumphant Montaigu Tournament in April.
Tyler played in an Under-17 European Championship qualifier for Scotland against Belarus in October and the next month Jack was in the England line-up for their qualifying win against Croatia.

The Fletchers joined the City academy in 2014 - when their father was still a player at United. A source who watched Jack in the City academy is adamant he will play for the United first team. Sources at United stressed the Fletchers would not have been recruited from City if the club did not see first-team potential in them.

Jack has already graced the Old Trafford pitch, long before his father first did five days after his 18th birthday against Hartlepool in the FA Youth Cup in 2002. Sir Alex Ferguson intended to give Darren his debut as a 16-year-old against Aston Villa in May 2000 yet Fletcher senior's first two years at United were stunted by injury.

Jack was virtuoso in the FA Youth Cup win against Derby County at Old Trafford last month and his raking half-volleyed pass made it possible for Ethan Williams to notch the only goal. Fletcher's technique made Ben Thornley, the fleet-footed Class of '92 winger on co-commentary for MUTV in the press box, purr before it had even reached Ethan Wheatley.
The memory is already soured. Swindon shocked United in the fourth round on Tuesday night with a 2-0 win at the County Ground.

Jack got a ticking off from the referee for backchat. One of his corners failed to beat the first man and the second seconds later went over everyone. He ended the game bickering with an opponent. Fletcher's father excelled at playing the opponent rather than the occasion and Jack will have to learn from a galling evening in Wiltshire.

United are reluctant to elaborate on the Fletcher twins' development. A source said staff want to "keep it as low-key as possible", perhaps conscious of overhyping two lads who would be in Year 12 if still at school, or fuelling any accusations of nepotism. An early ejection from the Youth Cup vindicates the reticence.

Tyler posed for his intimate unveiling photo, clutching a shirt with 'Fletcher 6', in the Old Trafford boardroom in August. In the background, there was a framed monochrome photograph of Ryan Giggs triumphantly hoisting the European Cup on the Manchester Airport tarmac in 2008. Peer closer and Darren is visible in the background on the passenger boarding steps.
On the same day, Jack stood on the Old Trafford pitch and brandished his own shirt. That was one way to tell which is which.

headline: Scoring 100 goals a season and sharing a Roy Keane trait - Dan Gore's Manchester United journey
body: Man United youngster Dan Gore has made excellent progress over the last 18 months, so the MEN spoke to two of his former coaches at Burnley to discuss his journey to the first-team at Old Trafford.
Dan Gore couldn't help but smile throughout his post-match interview after making his Manchester United debut.

Gore made his senior bow against Crystal Palace in the Carabao Cup and he fought an excitable grin as he answered questions. The game also coincided with his 19th birthday and his family were present to enjoy the occasion, which Gore described as 'truly special' after growing up supporting the club.

“It tops the list of birthdays," Gore said while trying to keep his composure. "I don’t think words can describe that feeling, seeing the fans, it is everything you’ve dreamed of, coming true. It means everything."
Gore became the 247th player to make his debut from the academy that night, reward for making excellent progress and convincing Erik ten Hag he was ready.
He trained with the first-team for 12 weeks before his debut and is known to 'train every day like his life depends on it', something which his former coaches at Burnley loved about him.

Although Gore is a Salford-lad and he idolised Wayne Rooney and Cristiano Ronaldo when he was a kid, he only joined United in 2018, having previously been at Burnley where he played as a forward, not a midfielder.

"He first came through the door when he was seven or eight," Lewis Craig told the Manchester Evening News. "Burnley were very good at recruiting the Scouse and Manc kids and Dan was a raw, inner-city Manchester lad.

"Those types seemed to have that little bit more extra bite than your local kids. He was a forward when he came to us and he’d either play wide left or right or as the number nine and he was the top scorer through his age groups.

"He was quick and very strong for his size. He always had aggression and he was one of the kids who played on the edge, in terms of maybe making the odd bad challenge, but it was interesting because he was always respectful.

"He had great finishing ability in his younger years, one-on-one, going past people and he always had that bit where he was a winner. If he was getting beat, there was nobody on the pitch who hated it more and you could see that fire in him. Dan had that brilliant, real f****** horrible side to him, but he'd always be respectful with coaches and it wasn't a surprise when I saw him three months ago and he ran over and gave me a hug when I hadn’t seen him for years."

Gore joined United at 13 and the decision was made to drop him deeper into midfield. "My last day working for Burnley, I had to deliver his review to his dad," Craig said when asked about his position change.

"Although he was a great striker, I didn’t think he scored poachers goals, like your Harry Kane or Ole Gunnar Solskjaer. He scored amazing goals and he was off the charts, but I thought he could be a better instinctive finisher.

"I remember his dad saying thank you because all he'd had for a couple of years was people telling him how good he was and nobody had said things to work on. He was prolific and he’d beat a few men and fire one into the top corner, but if someone wrapped a ball across the 18-yard box at speed, he probably didn’t have that instinctive finish in him every time.

"But he worked on it religiously. He always worked on stuff and he was in training early, even as a kid. I never pictured him as a midfielder because although his awareness was decent, it's different playing in that role. He’s developed his awareness now and when I see him driving the ball in midfield, it’s similar to how he played back then."
Mike Hargreaves, who considers Gore as the best young player he's encountered, is another former Burnley coach who worked with the youngster and he spoke to the MEN about that period.

"I worked with Danny at Burnley from Under-9s to Under-12s and I took that age group all the way through, so I worked with him for quite a while, and outside of Burnley with my own coaching," Hargreaves said.

"Some of the things I’ve seen him do for United, he’s been doing since back then. He’s dropped deeper now, but when he played up front for Burnley he'd score over 100 goals each season and I’m not even exaggerating.

"There was a game at Blackburn once when we built possession well, Dan picked the ball up inside his own half and he just started running past people and he ended up finishing it off, which was unbelievable. There was another time when he faced someone up, stopped the ball dead and did the Yannick Bolaise showboating thing when he bent down and flicked the grass, so he had a little bit of cheekiness about him.

"He was a matchwinner and they were a really good group. I always thought It was just a matter of time before United would come in for him and I always expected that. I can’t think of many times he didn't have a good day."

Hargreaves continued: "His real stand-out qualities were he was hard-working, aggressive, he put himself about and he was a really exciting dribbler. He was fantastic with the ball and capable of sprinting repeatedly. His speed endurance was phenomenal, even at those ages. His attitude was great and he was demanding of his teammates and the standards of the session.

"Towards the end of Under-11s, we had a tournament on Blackpool’s pitch and it was a full-day affair. We played United in the final of that and Danny scored. They were just completely top draw that day as a group.

"I remember building up to that tournament for a few weeks and reiterating what we were building up to and you’d see a change in him, almost like a switch being flicked and a refocus. You could see he wanted to win."
The burning desire to improve and win has seen Gore become a member of the first-team squad with Ten Hag in charge and he's worn the captain's armband when playing in academy matches this season.

"He’s captain material I'd say," Craig added. "Almost like your old-school Roy Keane type with hard challenges, but he’s got unbelievable quality on the ball because he was a forward in the past as well.

"In that Under-21 group at United, there have been the likes of Shola Shoretire and Isak Hasen-Aaroen but it seems like there's been something missing in them, which doesn’t seem to be the case with Dan. If you leave him in an environment long enough he thrives and I think it's fair to say that Dan wasn’t a Burnley type of player, in the sense that he was probably beyond Burnley in terms of his ability.

"He would have played for Burnley’s first-team if he was still there and Sean Dyche would have been all over him, but there was always an acceptance of Dan was Salford, Man United and there were murmurings going on in the background. Kids get poached in academies all the time, but I think Burnley got looked after with the deal when he did go over. And I think he was given certain guarantees because United knew the talent they were getting."

Gore was part of the FA Youth Cup winning side in 2022 and although Alejandro Garnacho was the poster boy of that campaign, his partnership with Kobbie Mainoo in midfield was instrumental in the success. More than 60,000 supporters watched the final at Old Trafford and Gore kissed the badge when the full time whistle went. It wasn't a surprise for a boy who used to wear a red thermal vest under his Burnley shirt.
"You can tell what Manchester United means to him when he plays," Craig said. "I went to the Youth Cup final and I just thought he was outstanding, doing the horrible side of the game really well.

"I thought out of possession, Dan was excellent, picking up second balls and showing all the stuff he's added to his game as a midfielder and you can see he's got a real understanding of the game now."

Hargreaves was also in the crowd and he briefly talked to Gore during the celebrations. "I saw him right at the end when they were doing the lap of honour because I was sitting near the front, so I went down and shouted.

"He said 'aaaah Mike!' and I congratulated him, so it was nice to have that moment and I did have to laugh because near the end of the Youth Cup final, he was tapping his head and telling people to focus.

"That’s stuck with me because it’s something I do myself. We had great times at Burnley and he was the star of the group. I’ve got a great relationship with him and his dad, who was always very grateful for us looking after him."

Gore has been on an upward trajectory since and Bruno Fernandes is understood to have been very welcoming to the youngster, taking a hands-on role in his integration into the first-team. Sources have also indicated Jonny Evans has been especially supportive and offered Gore plenty of advice since they started training together in mid-July, which the 19-year-old has appreciated.

"You’re around top players every day at United and you either adapt or die," Craig said. "Even if he ends up making 100 appearances for United in the Premier League or with another club, he'll get the most out of himself.
"Ten Hag has been known for developing youngsters at Ajax and he doesn’t put people in who aren’t good enough. I'm really proud of him and it's lovely when you bump into him, or get a text."

Hargreaves echoed those comments: "It’s been brilliant to see him progress and I’m a United fan myself, so I'm extremely pleased because it's more than he deserves. I genuinely think he embodies what a United player should be, bringing excitement, being hard-working and holding himself in the right way."

Gore recently shaved his head - going for a buzzcut style - and there was a large smile on his face when he revealed his new haircut to his amused teammates at Carrington. That wide grin doesn't seem to be going away anytime soon.

headline: Manchester United make decision on Amad's future
body: Amad joined Man United from Atalanta in October 2020 but he has only played 10 times for the club.
Manchester United are planning to keep Amad beyond the closure of the January transfer window.
United expect Facundo Pellistri to join Granada on loan and believe Amad has an important role to play in the squad.
Amad, 21, made his first United appearance in more than two years as a substitute in the 2-1 defeat to Nottingham Forest on January 30.
The Ivory Coast international missed the FA Cup third round win against Wigan Athletic through illness and he could return to the squad for the fourth round tie at Newport County next week.
United signed Amad for £19million rising to £37m from Atalanta on transfer deadline day in October 2020 and the winger has played 10 times for the club.
EXCLUSIVE: Brailsford meeting former United staff with 'brutal' changes planned

Amad spent the second half of the 2021-22 season on loan at Rangers and shone during a season-long loan at Sunderland last term. Amad scored 14 goals in 42 games for the Championship side as Sunderland reached the play-offs.
Pellistri was due to leave on loan in the summer but ended up remaining at United after Amad sustained a knee injury in the pre-season win against Arsenal in July.
Amad returned to training in early December and he performed creditably off the bench in the loss at Forest.

headline: Manchester United legends Roy Keane and Ryan Giggs didn't speak for six months after blazing row
body: Manchester United legends Roy Keane and Ryan Giggs once had a blazing row at the club's training ground, with Gary Neville caught in the middle of the feuding pair
Manchester United legends Roy Keane and Ryan Giggs had a long-term disagreement that involved early morning arguments due to 'irritating' actions.

The pair, who played together for the Red Devils from 1993 to 2005, didn't speak for six months during their time at the club. Keane was upset with Giggs after the Welshman declined to represent the club at a function, a duty which would rotate around the dressing room.

"I was fuming with him," he shared on the Stick to Football podcast. “You know when you have to do something for your club – nobody wants to do anything at the club. I was like, ‘Giggs you have to do what [the club] wants, we’ve all done it and it’s just your turn next’.
EAD MORE: Rotating the stadium and Glazer's preference - what United could do with Old Trafford
"Giggs was obviously good with stuff like that. It was just that day he went ‘I’m not doing it’, and I was just irritated by him - simple as that, and we dragged it on for a few months.”

The situation escalated at the training ground one day, with Gary Neville finding himself in the middle of the arguing pair. He recalled: “I walked in at 8am into the dressing room, I’m in there first, and then Giggsy comes in and sits there. There were only three of us in the dressing room – me, Roy and Giggsy. They started arguing.

“I remember Roy saying you’ve done stuff for your testimonial or something like that and this went on for about five minutes. I thought, ‘I’m getting f***ing out of here!’ There’s nothing I can do so I walked out, I came back in 10 minutes later and they were still going!’”
Keane also had a falling out with former defender Gary Pallister, not speaking to him for a whole year after he'd left a night out early. He's since made up with both.

headline: Brentford manager makes Christian Eriksen transfer admission amid Manchester United exit reports
body: Christian Eriksen returned to the Premier League with Brentford before his move to Man Utd two years ago.
Brentford manager Thomas Frank says he would always welcome Christian Eriksen back to the club amid reports linking the midfielder with a summer exit from Manchester United.

The Denmark international established himself as one of United's most important players after he arrived at the club as a free agent in the summer of 2022, but has fallen down the pecking order at Old Trafford since.
Eriksen remains a valuable squad player to Erik ten Hag but is now behind both Kobbie Mainoo and Scott McTominay in the pecking order and could drop further down once Mason Mount is fit again.
Reports this week suggested Galatasaray have made Eriksen their primary summer target, but a return to Brentford could make sense for all parties.

The 31-year-old has started just nine Premier League games this season, and with less than 18 months left on his contract, this summer could be the final chance for United to cash in rather than risk losing him on a free.
It is certainly a proposal that Brentford would consider, and Frank insists that while he is at the club, Eriksen will always be welcomed back.
"He will always be welcome back! Christian will always be," he told Danish magazine Tipsbladet. "I think he knows that well. And we know he had a good time here.

"I understood well why he went to United back then, and I've said that publicly. I also think he's done well. Of course, he had an injury before Christmas for a while. But if Christian wants, he's very welcome."

It's the January transfer window once again, but despite United's indifferent start to the season, it remains to be seen whether they'll be able to bring any new players to Old Trafford this month. While the emphasis this January is on outgoings, with several players set to be sold or loaned out, there remains a possibility of a loan signing or two before February arrives.

Our team of experts are on top of all the goings-on at Old Trafford for the remainder of the window and beyond, and you can get the latest updates and inside information to your phone by joining our new free WhatsApp community. You can also join the 50,000 (and growing!) band of United fans who are following our WhatsApp Channel.

We also treat our community members to special offers, promotions, and adverts from us and our partners. If you don’t like our community, you can check out any time you like. If you’re curious, you can read our Privacy Notice.

headline: Old Trafford stadium plans could help Sir Jim Ratcliffe address Man United's 'elephant in the room'
body: Sir Jim Ratcliffe has been told he would be tackling one of Manchester United's biggest problems if he were to redevelop Old Trafford, with claims also suggesting a new stadium could be considered
Football finance expert Kieran Maguire believes Sir Jim Ratcliffe would be addressing the "elephant in the room" at Manchester United if he were to rebuild Old Trafford.

The Telegraph has revealed plans of the INEOS chairman - who is waiting for his 25 per cent in United to be ratified by the Premier League - to create a "Wembley of the North" and completely revamp the club's home of 114 years.
It is claimed talks with the Mayor of Greater Manchester, Andy Burnham, have already begun over building a "state-of-the-art" venue that could end up costing in the region of £1.5bn.

As part of Ratcliffe's £1.03bn investment in United, the 71-year-old was made to commit a further £237m towards the development of Old Trafford. It is something the Glazer family has failed to do since acquiring the club back in 2005.
EXCLUSIVE: Arteta Arsenal comparison fuelling United's belief in Ten Hag

As a result, Maguire, who teaches finance and accounting at the University of Liverpool and hosts the Price of Football podcast, thinks Ratcliffe would be tackling one of United's biggest issues but insists a deal to fund the project could be a "key problem".

“The state of Old Trafford has been an elephant in the room for many years,” said Maguire, in conversation with Football Insider. “It’s not befitting of a club of the status and stature of Manchester United.

“You talk to fans who sit in the Stretford End and they’ll point out all the failings in terms of facilities, catering space and so on. So it’s welcoming to hear that there are talks taking place between Manchester Council and INEOS.

“It’s going to be a very, very expensive transformation if it does take place looking at what’s happened at Spurs. If Manchester United want to replicate the quality of their facilities and have a 90,000-capacity stadium then it will cost them £2bn. Where that money’s going to come from is going to be a key problem.“
According to the Telegraph, Ratcliffe could seek funding from the Government for a possible renovation of Old Trafford as part of the recent north-vs-south "levelling up" project.

headline: Gary Neville sends Marcus Rashford Liverpool warning after Manchester United star's night out
body: The former Man United captain has told Rashford to be careful of who he surrounds himself with after hitting the headlines following a night of clubbing last month.

Gary Neville says it is important for Marcus Rashford to ensure he is surrounded by “the right group of people” and has urged him not to be easily persuaded into things that could hamper his career - hinting that is where his Liverpool rivals in the 90s fell short.

Rashford missed last month’s FA Cup clash with Newport County after reporting ill two days earlier having being seen clubbing in Belfast during the week. Manchester United were informed that images of Rashford on a night out were from Wednesday, with players having a day off on Thursday before the striker called in unwell on Friday, despite contrasting rumours.

The player said he was available for the trip to Newport on Sunday morning but with the team and tactics already prepared, United asked Rashford to train at Carrington instead. In the build-up to the tie, Erik ten Hags described the case as an “internal matter” that he would “deal with”.
EXCLUSIVE: Arteta Arsenal comparison fuelling United's belief in Ten Hag
After talks with the 26-year-old and his agent the following Monday, Ten Hag declared it was “case closed” before starting him in the 4-3 away win at Wolves, during which he netted the opening goal.

Neville has told Rashford his next step going forward is to make sure off-field activity does not impact his profession - and claimed United's rivals Liverpool could have been more successful in the 90s had they curbed their partying. Speaking on the Stick To Football podcast, Neville said: “We were talking about Marcus Rashford last week, about having that right group of people around him.

“You can’t do the things that your friends are doing, so if you’re influenced by your friends, there is that element of, ‘Oh go on then,’ and that ‘Go on then’ would have done me. I never went out in the first five or six years of my career at United, I don’t think I could have done.
“To me, it was work ethic and love for the club. I listened, trained, and wanted to do well. These are the things that are the biggest factor [in becoming a professional footballer].”

Neville felt as though that diligence and punctuality was a major part in United’s success in the 1990s. He contrasted the mentality of him and his teammates at United to those at Liverpool during that decade of dominance.

‌Neville added: “At that time [1992/93] Liverpool had a talented group of players, and I don’t dismiss that some of them were as talented as we were, like [Steve] McManaman, [Robbie] Fowler, Jamie Redknapp, and a couple of others. Their senior players were big drinkers.
“They had a talented group at Liverpool and there was one year where they were pushing us for the title, in 1995/96, but our senior players, I felt, were more professional and were more talented.
‌“To me, there wasn’t an excess [of drinking], where we put games in doubt, but I remember seeing Liverpool lads at Cheerleaders [nightclub].

‌“Cheerleaders on a Wednesday night, I went a couple of times and I remember the Liverpool lads were in the corner, the United lads would go home around 1am but the Liverpool lads were [there until] 4am, 5am on a Wednesday.”

headline: 'A different way' - Marcus Rashford told how he can emulate Roy Keane at Manchester United
body: Man United ace Marcus Rashford has scored three goals in his last four Premier League games - but Gary Neville and Jamie Carragher say he must offer more leadership to his team

Gary Neville and Jamie Carragher have urged Marcus Rashford to become a leader at Manchester United following last month's disciplinary issue. The 26-year-old forward reported ill for training ahead of the Red Devils' FA Cup clash against Newport County, but it later transpired that he had been partying in Belfast just hours prior.

Rashford missed the trip to South Wales, with Erik ten Hag attributing his absence to a 'disciplinary matter'. He was subject to lots of criticism from supporters and pundits alike, with some casting doubt over his future at Old Trafford.

Once the issue was dealt with in-house and a resolution was found, Rashford bounced back with aplomb. The England international marked his return from the social media storm with a goal to put United ahead against Wolves at Molineux.

With a Champions League qualification spot and a place in the England squad at stake, Neville and Carragher have encouraged Rashford to source inspiration from the likes of Roy Keane and Steven Gerrard.

Speaking on the Stick to Football podcast, brought to you by Sky Bet, the former Red Devils defender said: "Roy Keane only started to assume the mantle of being the dominant inspirational character at the age of 26 at Manchester United, but Marcus Rashford is nothing like Roy Keane in personality or character."

Then, the former Liverpool centre-back added: "Marcus Rashford doesn’t need to be like Roy Keane, he must lead and show character in a different way. Someone like Steven Gerrard, who was a completely different player to Marcus Rashford.
"Someone like me who would be shouting and screaming at people, at the referee and other players, and Stevie showed leadership through his whole ability and the respect he had from the other players.
"I’m not saying Rashford needs to go round shouting at everyone, but his body language needs to change and being the person, you want him to be when someone becomes a leader.

"I feel like when I’m watch Trent Alexander-Arnold this season, even though his numbers might be the same, it’s his body language and his change in demeanour on the pitch which has changed as he’s getting older."

headline: Kobbie Mainoo sends heartwarming message to Manchester United fan whose father passed away
body: Kobbie Mainoo has touched the hearts of thousands after the teenager sent a Manchester United fan a moving message on social media

Kobbie Mainoo has sent a heartwarming message to a grieving Manchester United fan whose father sadly passed away last week. The 18-year-old midfielder received a tweet from a supporter, thanking him for netting the winner against Wolves on Thursday evening.

Mainoo capped off a brilliant performance at Molineux with his first Premier League goal, securing the Red Devils three crucial points in the race for top four. It was a night to remember for the teenage sensation, but his strike meant a lot more to one fan who was able to celebrate one more stoppage-time winner with his father.

The post read: "Really keen to try and get someone at Man Utd or @MU_Foundation get this message to Kobbie, so any shares or retweets would be much appreciated. Sadly my Father lost his brave battle against cancer yesterday.

"The last game we watched together was the Wolves game, just the two of us in his hospital room. When Wolves equalised we were both so frustrated. I have never willed United to score more than that moment and then Kobbie Mainoo steps up with an amazing winner.

"Seeing Dad's arm in the air, a smile on his face and declaring 'that’s why you watch United'. When he saw that you were doing an interview, he insisted that I stay so he could listen. I know football should be about winning trophies, but you will never score a more important goal for our family Kobbie.
"You are already a hero in our household and you are now my 7-year-old's favourite player. Thank you for a truly brilliant and special moment. I am sure your career will bring many of them."

Thousands of United supporters from across the world flooded the post with likes and messages of support. The touching tweet quickly found Mainoo, who with a great show of class, invited the fan to watch a game at Old Trafford with their son.

The England Under-19 international said: "Hi Daniel, Kobbie here. I saw your message on Twitter and was really touched by your story. I'm really sorry about the passing of your father and I'm glad you could share such a special moment together and I could play a small part in that.
"I wanted to invite you and your son to a game soon so we'll get in touch and get everything sorted. Stay strong and I'll see you soon."

headline: Manchester United might get what they want from Jadon Sancho's move to Dortmund
body: Jadon Sancho left Man United in the January transfer window and he's enjoyed a decent start to life back at Dortmund
Jadon Sancho struggled following his 2021 move to Manchester United and he recently returned to Borussia Dortmund on loan.

This was seen as a good deal for all parties. Sancho was handed a chance to rediscover form, which could bring about a future renaissance at United, Erik ten Hag did not have to deal with a player he had clashed with and Dortmund signed a player they knew would produce the goods.

So, how have Sancho, Dortmund and United got on since the England international completed his return to Germany? United have played four games since Sancho left the club and they have yet to suffer defeat.
Having drawn their first game with Tottenham Hotspur, United won the next three games, scoring three or more goals in each of these wins.

It is evident that United have not missed Sancho since he moved back to the Westfalenstadion, though that's not much of a surprise given he had been exiled from first-team duties anyway and so their matchday squad looked no different for Sancho's departure.
As for Dortmund, they hadn't won in seven games before Sancho returned, with their last win coming in the Champions League against AC Milan on November 28.
But since the day Sancho re-signed for the club, Dortmund have won three of their four matches, bringing them back into contention for Champions League qualification for next season.
Dortmund will now be confident that they can once again qualify for Europe’s biggest club competition. And this is partly to do with the impact Sancho has had since returning to Germany.

In his first spell with the club, Sancho registered 50 goals and 64 assists in the four seasons he played for Dortmund. The loanee has picked up where he left off in Germany and has already registered two assists.

Sancho has brought another dimension to the Dortmund attack, and while that may not have resulted in him scoring any goals, the creative nature of the player has brought about more chances and space for his teammates.
So, with all parties benefitting from this loan deal, what should be done at the end of the season?

There is no agreement in place for Dortmund to take the player on a permanent deal, but if he continues to shine, they may want to re-sign him and it's unlikely United would stand in his way, even if he does find form in Germany.

Sancho definitely seems to have played his final game for United, and with his price tag set to rise with every impressive display for Dortmund, this looks like a loan deal that has actually worked out well for all involved.

headline: Lisandro Martinez injury gives Manchester United a specific problem
body: Man United defender Lisandro Martinez faces another spell on the sidelines after suffering a knee injury against West Ham United at the weekend.
Former centre-back Rio Ferdinand fears the loss of Lisandro Martinez to injury risks derailing Manchester United's momentum.

The Argentine is expected to face a minimum of eight weeks on the sidelines after suffering a knee injury in Sunday's 3-0 win over West Ham United at Old Trafford. The defender was forced off with just under 20 minutes remaining after his knee buckled under the weight of Hammers right-back Vladimir Coufal.
A statement released by United on Monday said: "Lisandro Martinez has sustained an injury to the medial collateral ligament in his knee and is expected to be out of action for at least eight weeks."

Martinez, who was signed from Ajax in July 2022, was making just his fourth appearance since returning from a foot injury that had seen him sidelined since September. After returning via the bench against Tottenham Hotspur last month, he started the FA Cup win over Newport County before featuring from the start in the Premier League wins against Wolves and West Ham.

He was excellent in both meaning his presence at the back will be sorely missed over the coming weeks. And for Ferdinand, it is a huge blow to United's hopes of maintaining their recent run of good form, not least because it dismantles his left-sided relationship with Luke Shaw.

Ferdinand, speaking on Vibe with Five ahead of United's official statement on Martinez being released, said: "He got a little injury. He's done his knee. I see he tweaked it. I think that looks like ligaments. He tried to carry on and then said, 'No, no, no I've got to go'. So, listen, if he's out, it kills it.

"You can see with him and Luke Shaw on that side, when they're together, they look so dominant, they look so confident, they look so composed with the ball. And those two are really good with the ball in terms of setting up attacks, the ball generally comes from that side.

"Any of the good stuff United do, Martinez, even you see for the first goal, he clips it in. Yes it goes to [Kurt] Zouma and he heads it down and Casemiro intercepts and we get the goal off that, but it's because Martinez is playing forward, he's playing forceful passes. So that will be disappointing. United have had so many injuries and he's one of them that's been out of a while and he's probably one of their most influential players."

headline: Sir Alex Ferguson has already warned Manchester United ahead of Aston Villa fixture
body: Manchester United travel to Aston Villa in the Premier League on Sunday seeking to make up ground in the battle for Champions League football

Manchester United have been seeking to replicate Sir Alex Ferguson's success since the day he left Old Trafford for the final time. This weekend they will need to heed a warning from the United great.

The Reds won the last of their Premier League titles in Ferguson's final season a decade ago and won't be ending that drought this term. Instead, the focus for Erik ten Hag and his squad is to try and ensure Champions League football next season with United currently sixth but looking upwards after a 3-0 weekend win over West Ham.

Seven goals and six points in four days has raised optimism of a strong finish for the Reds, who have struggled for much of this season. Early exits from Europe and the Carabao Cup raised the pressure on Ten Hag but United, led by exciting young talents Rasmus Hojlund, Alejandro Garnacho and Kobbie Mainoo, are targeting a strong finish to a campaign which could also yield a trophy in the FA Cup.

If the Reds are to gatecrash the top four, or perhaps more realistically fifth - which could well be enough to secure a spot in the newly-expanded Champions League - then they are likely going to need to reel in one or both of Tottenham Hotspur and Aston Villa.

It's the latter who United face this weekend with the Midlanders enjoying a superb campaign under Unai Emery. He has transformed the club into European contenders and they boast an enviable home record despite being beaten by Newcastle United in their last Villa Park fixture.

United, while rightly full of confidence after their last two performances, will not be under-estimating Villa and if they need any further reminders they only need to listen to Fergie and his prophetic words on the eve of the season. The Reds great spoke to NBC Sports ahead of United's season opener against Wolves and had nothing but positive words for Villa, despite the fact they'd been beaten 5-1 by Newcastle on the opening weekend.
"To be honest with you, I watched Aston Villa and I can't believe the scoreline. Honestly Aston Villa played fantastic football and just lost to bad goals," Ferguson said.

"Newcastle are going to be very difficult to beat, in their own ground in particular, and their manager has done a great job there. It's a surprising game, football. You can play teams off the pitch and not score - that's what Aston Villa did."
His opinion has been borne out over the past few months. United will need to bear it mind come kick-off on Sunday.

headline: Cristiano Ronaldo 'likes' Manchester United birthday message despite feeling 'betrayed' by club
body: Cristiano Ronaldo, who currently plays for Al-Nassr in the Saudi Pro League, issued a statement after leaving Manchester United for the second time in November 2022
Cristiano Ronaldo still has a place for Manchester United in his heart even after an unfortunate run-in with Erik ten Hag.

The forward left the club for the second time amid issues back in November 2022, but its clear he still cares about the team. Ronaldo returned to Old Trafford in summer 2021, after six brilliant years with Sir Alex Ferguson.
However, his comeback didn't last long. Despite scoring 24 goals in 38 matches during the 2021/22 season, Ronaldo's role was reduced under new boss Erik ten Hag and their relationship soured.
EXCLUSIVE: Arteta Arsenal comparison fuelling Manchester United's belief in Erik ten Hag
As a result, Ronaldo brought an early end to his contract, agreeing to a mutual parting with United in November 2022. Still, his connection with the club lingers.
On his 39th birthday, United sent him good wishes over Instagram, complete with 'Viva Ronaldo' in the caption. Ronaldo himself approved of the message by liking the post on his profile.

These days, Ronaldo is playing for Al-Nassr in the Saudi Pro League. He previously revealed in an emotional interview with Piers Morgan that he felt "betrayed" by United and criticised Ten Hag, particularly dissatisfied with how things unfolded under his management at Old Trafford.

Given the nature of his comments, his departure came as no surprise when it was announced a few days later. Reacting to the news, Ronaldo issued a statement which read: "Following conversations with Manchester United we have mutually agreed to end our contract early.

"I love Manchester United and I love the fans, that will never ever change. However, it feels like the right time for me to seek a new challenge. I wish the team every success for the remainder of the season and for the future."

Since leaving the Premier League, Ronaldo has scored 44 goals in 50 games for Al-Nassr in Saudi Arabia, who are currently second in the Saudi Pro League. They are seven points behind Al-Hilal, who haven't lost a game this season.
In total, Ronaldo scored 145 goals for Manchester United in the 345 appearances he made across his two spells at the club.

headline: When will Lisandro Martinez be fit? Injury timescale and return date for Manchester United star
body: Lisandro Martinez faces another spell on the sidelines after being forced off injured in Man United's 3-0 win over West Ham United on Sunday.
Manchester United defender Lisandro Martinez faces up to at least two months on the sidelines after suffering a knee injury in Sunday's 3-0 win over West Ham United at Old Trafford.

The centre-back, who joined the club from Ajax in July 2022, was forced off with just under 20 minutes of normal time remaining after his knee buckled under the weight of Hammers defender Vladimir Coufal a few minutes earlier. He attempted to play on following the initial incident but went down a few minutes later and was unable to continue.

He was replaced by Raphael Varane, who partnered Harry Maguire at centre-back for the remainder of the game. United issued a statement on Monday evening to confirm the Argentine had suffered an injury to the medial collateral ligament in his knee and is expected to be sidelined for a period of at least eight weeks.

Having only returned from a lengthy injury lay-off in mid-January, it is a bitter pill for both Martinez and United to have to swallow. He was excellent in the victory at Wolves last Thursday night and up until being forced off at the weekend.

United's upcoming crop of fixtures, in addition to the clash with Manchester City, also feature a clash with Aston Villa this coming weekend and a tussle with Everton at Old Trafford on March 9. If United beat Forest or Bristol City in the FA Cup fifth-round, their quarter-final date will see their league fixture against Sheffield United on March 16 rearranged.

Fortunately for Martinez, the injury is not going to require surgery, meaning his rehabilitation will not be as lengthy as first feared. Nevertheless, the prospect of being without him for at least eight weeks is a massive blow for United, who heavily rely on his presence at the back.

If his recovery goes according to plan, an eight-week lay-off could see him return after the March international break, meaning he could be next available for the trip to the Gtech Community Stadium to face Brentford on March 30. Failing that, he could return at the beginning of April, with United facing Chelsea at Stamford Bridge on April 3 and then Liverpool at Old Trafford on April 6, though both fixture dates could still be rescheduled for television purposes.

After a busy start to April, United's fixture list eases slightly, with their next league game after the clash with Liverpool currently penciled in for April 13, which is the date of a trip to Bournemouth. The FA Cup semi-finals take place the following weekend.

headline: I nearly signed Ronaldinho for Man United - the move was done but I knew we'd fail for one reason
body: Manchester United were on the brink of signing Ronaldinho in 2003 before the Brazilian sensation ended up at Barcelona - and now ex-Red Devils CEO David Gill has explained why
Former Manchester United CEO David Gill has finally revealed why the club didn't sign Ronaldinho.
In 2003, after selling David Beckham to Real Madrid, United considered Ronaldinho as a replacement for their former No.7. However, the deal fell through and Ronaldinho went on to play for Barcelona.

Speaking on the VIBE with Five podcast, Gill explained that he and Peter Kenyon, who was chief executive at the time, met with Ronaldinho's agent and had the numbers all thrashed out - but something didn't feel right.
Gill remarked: "I just didn't get a good vibe. Barcelona were in there and I've done enough deals to know 'do they really want to come here' when you're buying something.
READ MORE:De Gea and Dalot give same Lisandro Martinez verdict after injury setback

"I just felt if Barcelona hadn't have been there we'd have got him. But if Barcelona were there, they were clearly his first choice, a Brazilian going to Barcelona - with all due respect notwithstanding the success of Manchester United, they were his first choice.

"If they hadn't had come up with the goods, we'd had all of the deal done. The numbers were done. I don't think it was anything we'd done wrong it was just that Barcelona had come in. We were close but no cigar."

Sir Alex Ferguson shared his thoughts on the chase for Ronaldinho, saying to GQ: "The attempt to buy Ronaldinho reflected the fact that United have always sported talismanic players. I was always hunting for that talent."
"My line of reasoning was, 'We're getting £25m for Beckham, and we're getting Ronaldinho for £19m'. For God's sake, wake up. It was a steal."

Choosing not to sign Ronaldinho led to United's three-year title drought, with Arsenal and Chelsea winning the English crown until 2007. By then, David Gill was CEO, having replaced Peter Kenyon in 2003.
Ronaldinho has said before that he almost signed for United. His teammate Kleberson told ESPN: "Ronaldinho told me he was going to Manchester. He kept saying to me, 'Come to Manchester!"
"I wanted to go, but I was worried because I didn't speak English and United didn't have any Portuguese speakers. But Ronaldinho persuaded me and I went to Manchester."

headline: Manchester United confirm Lisandro Martinez injury and give timeframe for return
body: Lisandro Martinez sustained a knee injury in the 66th minute of Man United's win against West Ham and was forced off five minutes later.
Lisandro Martinez is set for two months on the sidelines after he suffered knee ligament damage in the win against West Ham at Old Trafford.
Martinez's knee buckled under the weight of West Ham defender Vladimir Coufal in the 66th minute of United's 3-0 Premier League win at Old Trafford and he was forced off in the 71st minute.

The 26-year-old had a scan on Monday morning and although he is set for around eight weeks on the sidelines, it revealed he did not require surgery and the injury wasn't as bad as first feared, with the damage to the medial collateral ligament.
United manager Erik ten Hag described the injury as a "personal disaster" for Martinez, who recently returned from nearly four months out with a foot injury.
"He is very sad, very disappointed," Ten Hag said on Sunday. "We all feel really with him. First of all, it's a personal disaster when it's really bad. But let's wait for what it is.
"But for the team, also it is really bad because he definitely brings us a lot."

headline: Mason Greenwood has new transfer option and more Manchester United rumours
body: Your latest Manchester United transfer news as Mason Greenwood is attracting further interest from La Liga
Manchester United loanee Mason Greenwood is reportedly on a shortlist of forwards being weighed up by Spanish giants Atletico Madrid.

The 22-year-old, who has scored seven goals while on loan at Spanish side Getafe this campaign, has not played for United since being suspended by the club in January 2022 following accusations of rape, assault and controlling and coercive behaviour. The case was dropped by the Crown Prosecution Service after a lengthy investigation that concluded last year.

Greenwood is out of contract in 2025 and is largely expected to leave Old Trafford in the summer, with Atletico the latest side to be linked with a move for the one-cap England international. According to the Telegraph, Diego Simeone's side are still in the hunt for a forward after a move for Juventus' Moise Kean fell through last month.

The forward, who it is claimed has "impressed other Spanish teams" with his performances in La Liga this season, has also been linked with a move to Barcelona. Back at Old Trafford meanwhile, United could be handed a boost in their rumoured pursuit of Stuttgart forward Serhou Guirassy, who was linked with a move to the Reds by Sky Sports back in December.
EXCLUSIVE: Arteta Arsenal comparison fuelling United's belief in Ten Hag

Sky Sports claimed that United were "monitoring" the 27-year-old's progress in the Bundesliga, having scored 18 goals in his first 14 appearances across all competitions. According to journalist Fabrizio Romano, Guirassy's release clause - which was said to stand at £17.25m in the January transfer window - will remain valid in the summer transfer window.

It is claimed several Premier League clubs are interested in the Guinea international. Links to Guirassy can be justified, with United underperforming in the final third this campaign and as a result, have only scored 31 goals in 23 games.
For comparison, Manchester City and Liverpool have scored 54 and 52 goals respectively. Only eight Premier League sides have scored fewer goals than Erik ten Hag's side.

headline: Wonderkid who downed Manchester United finds idea of joining Premier League rivals 'fun'
body: Copenhagen forward Roony Bardghji has spoken out about the prospect of a summer transfer window move after helping knock Man United out of the Champions League

Swedish football starlet Roony Bardghji has confessed that he would find it 'fun' to join his international teammate Lucas Bergvall at Tottenham. Bergvall turned down Barcelona to agree a move to Spurs on transfer deadline day, but his switch from Swedish top-tier club Djurgardens won't be official until the summer.

Bergvall, who previously had trials at Manchester United, couldn't join Spurs last Thursday as the British transfer deadline fell just hours before his 18th birthday. By summer, he might have a familiar face joining him at the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium.

That's because Spurs are also reportedly interested in Copenhagen forward Bardghji. The 18-year-old is known to Manchester United fans after scoring against them in a 4-3 Champions League win earlier this season.

Several Premier League clubs are said to be keen on the £20m-rated player, who, unlike Bergvall, hasn't yet made his senior international debut for Sweden. Spurs will compete with Newcastle and Aston Villa for Bardghji's signature.
However, Spurs might have an edge over their rivals after Bardghji admitted that he likes the idea of teaming up with Bergvall.
When asked about joining Bergvall at Spurs, Bardghji told SportBladet: "It's fun to think about. You never know, it could happen. Hard to say now."

Bardghji, a talented left-footed player who can play in different positions up front, has been compared to football legend Lionel Messi. This season, he's scored nine goals, including one against Man Utd, and he's shared that Messi was his hero as a kid.
"It was always Messi. No one else when I was young," Bardghji said in an interview with The Athletic.

Meanwhile, Bergvall has talked about how he chatted with Dejan Kulusevski before deciding to join Spurs. Both Swedish players, they have played together for their country and started at the same academy.
"We talked a little before," Bergvall mentioned to SportBladet.

"In general, how the club works, how they work, how they train, what the days look like. It wasn't a persuasive talk like that. He just said the club was great and I noticed that when I got there. I got an incredible reception, it's a very family club but incredible people."

headline: Lisandro Martinez injury will tell Manchester United the one player they can't afford to be without
body: Lisandro Martinez has a case to be viewed as Manchester United's most important player but there are other candidates
Erik ten Hag vowed that Manchester United's results and performance levels would improve once he recovered a crop of key players from injury.

Following Sunday's 3-0 triumph over West Ham United, United have now won each of their last three matches, plundering 11 goals in the process. Some of the football on show, particularly in the first half at Wolves last week, has been been among the best they have produced all season.

United's upturn in fortunes has coincided with the returns of the likes of Luke Shaw and Casemiro. Lisandro Martinez, too, had more than played his part up until suffering another injury problem in the win over the Hammers.

The Argentine faces at least eight weeks on the sidelines with a knee problem, meaning his return from a previous injury has been cut frustratingly short. It means Ten Hag must now find a solution to limit the impact of his absence.

Martinez, in the opinion of many, has been United's most successful signing of the Ten Hag era thus far. Therefore, MEN Sport's football writers have had their say on which player they believe United cannot afford to be without.

Right now, it has to be Rasmus Hojlund. For all the other issues within the United squad, the biggest problem has so often been a lack of goals and a focal point of attack, and he has helped to address it.

After a difficult start at the club, the 21-year-old has now hit his stride and has been a big part of everything they have done right in recent weeks. What is most pleasing is that he is scoring all different types of goals and is getting better with every one that finds the net.

Ultimately, a lot of the other issues in the squad can be glossed over as long as goals are being scored, and Hojlund is a vital cog to United’s hopes for the remainder of the season. He’d be starting every game even if they had another fit striker; the fact that they don’t just makes him that bit more important.

United have a lot of important individuals within their ranks, but are any of them more influential than Martinez? It is not often you consider a centre-back to be quite so valuable but the Argentine is paramount to the way Ten Hag likes his team to play.
As well as being an aggressive, well-rounded defender, his ball-playing ability is top-notch. His left foot is capable of opening up angles that United would not otherwise be able to find.

He is an excellent passer of the ball and he is comfortable striding out from the back with possession and moving into midfield. That was highlighted in the build-up to the first goal against West Ham.

Furthermore, Matinez, over time, has formed a solid partnership with Shaw at left-back. Between them, they form 50 per cent of United's strongest back-four and are critical to United's build-up play in the first phase, progressing the ball from deep.

What Martinez lacks in height, he makes up for in technical ability. Had his first season at Old Trafford not been cut short by a foot injury last April, he would have been a worthy contender for the team of the season.

Martinez's first stint out of the side this season proved he is the most important player for United at present. Last season, the Reds were defensively sound. Even if they were goal-shy, you could rely on the defensive partnership of Martinez and Raphael Varane to see them through.

However, United struggled to find an appropriate alternative to the Argentine in his injury absence. Jonny Evans, Victor Lindelof and Luke Shaw were all experimented in the centre of defence and while each player has had their moments, they don't inspire the same confidence as Martinez.

He is tenacious and conducts himself with the sort of character on the pitch which United fans have come to expect from their team. When you go to Old Trafford, there seems to be a greater atmosphere from the stands when Martinez is on the pitch and he has barely put a foot wrong since arriving. United supporters will feel unsettled by his eight-week injury layoff and it will be interesting to see if those who remain can step up to the plate.

United rely on Bruno Fernandes immeasurably. The midfielder, yet to miss a game through injury since his arrival four years ago, leads the goal contributions chart with 14 this season - seven goals and assists apiece.

All three of his Premier League goals have been match-winners and, for all his animated on-field gesticulations, he is a loud and present leader on the pitch. United have looked devoid of creativity when Fernanades has been played out on the right wing, which has only happened three times this season.

In the last three seasons, Fernandes has been missing for three games through suspension and United only managed to score once. His link-up play is vital to United’s forward play, and they would be worse off than they currently are without him.
In the Premier League alone this season, Fernandes has completed 1,206 passes, more than 300 more than any f his team-mates. He has also had nearly 350 more touches than any other United player.

Last season’s other top performers, Marcus Rashford and Casemiro, have both dropped off this season but Fernandes has remained consistent despite the mire. Goodness knows where the team would be without his input.

headline: Gary Neville spots major problem Kobbie Mainoo could have at Manchester United
body: Gary Neville has given his thoughts on the current crop of Man United youngsters, including Kobbie Mainoo, and he doesn't think they have the same support system he enjoyed
Gary Neville has expressed his worries about the new generation of stars at Manchester United, saying they may struggle due to a lack of leaders in the dressing room.

The former United player, who was part of the famous Class of 92, thinks that the current crop of young players like Kobbie Mainoo don't have the same support system he had. Mainoo has been a shining star for United this season, becoming a regular in Erik ten Hag's midfield.

He's leading a group of young players, including Omari Forson, Willy Kambwala and Amad Diallo, who are all vying for starting positions despite their tender years. But Neville has raised his concerns about the players' development.

"It's a massive factor, the dressing room that you come into as a young player and the influence and standard bearers in the dressing room," Neville said on the Stick to Football podcast, brought to you by Sky Bet.

"These [Manchester] United lads who have come through in the last five to eight years, if you’re a young lad coming through at Liverpool and Manchester City you’ve got a good chance, whereas if you’re at United now, you’re thinking who's guiding that dressing room."
Former United captain Keane agrees with Neville's views on the current team under Ten Hag. He joined United from Nottingham Forest in 1993 and was instantly impressed by the dressing room atmosphere.

"I loved the dressing room," he said. "I thought all these players were brilliant professionals, and I looked around and thought what a great group of people. Players like Bryan Robson, Ryan Giggs and Lee Sharpe, all amazing professional players.

"Remember the Cliff, our old training ground in Salford, I'd come in for a big fee at the time, but I was looking around the group and even the chat and the banter was great. My first pre-season we went to South Africa, and I couldn't believe how brilliant It was and how good the players were.

"We're talking about plenty of players when we played who would happily give tough love, but clearly no one is doing that at Manchester United for Marcus Rashford and that is one of the problems that the team has, they don't have that core group of players."

headline: Erik ten Hag and Sir Jim Ratcliffe set first challenge after Manchester United takeover
body: Manchester United's incoming co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe is expected to have his deal to acquire a minority stake in the club ratified by the Premier League soon
Former Manchester United striker Dwight Yorke has urged Erik ten Hag and Sir Jim Ratcliffe to end the club's reliance on the Sir Alex Ferguson glory years and welcome in a new era at the club.

INEOS founder Ratcliffe is set to arrive at Old Trafford officially this month after announcing on Christmas Eve his impending move. Once ratified by the Premier League, the British billionaire will oversee the football project with the Glazers taking a back seat in this department.

In his first statement, Ratcliffe insisted he wanted to make United a force again both domestically and in Europe. To do this, Yorke believes big changes need to be made beginning with the manager's press conferences.

"It really is a mixed bag at the moment and we really don’t know what we are going to get, it really is quite frustrating to look at, at times," Yorke explained to Sky Sports. "I think we have to be a little bit clearer in our style of play.
"I think the leadership qualities can be a little bit more assertive, rather than on the back foot. I think we are a little bit on the back foot from the press conference.

"There are always a lot of negatives, and a press conference never starts on an upbeat [note]. It is always trying to fight things off and I think that is something we need to improve on and get that negativity off our backs.

"We need to move forward from the Fergie Era. There has to be a cut-off time when enough is enough and it is time to move the club forward and I feel we are still in a bit of a limbo which is quite frustrating."

headline: David Gill has given INEOS their Manchester United priority
body: Man Utd could get a new stadium and training ground under Ineos investment but there are bigger issues to solve.

Manchester United fans will have different wishes for what they want to happen to the club once the Ineos investment is ratified. Yet they will all share one unified hope: for United to become the best team in the world again.

Sir Jim Ratcliffe is looking at ways to revolutionise the club once he is officially in charge, with talk of stadium redevelopment once again making headlines this week. The Manchester Evening News revealed last year United co-chairman Joel Glazer's preference is to preserve the heritage of the 113-year-old stadium with a renovation rather than a rebuild, though it has been suggested Ratcliffe favours the reverse.

It will become a more pressing issue in the long term, as will the redevelopment options of the club's training facilities, with United open to relocating from their Carrington training complex due to the logistical issues of expanding the site. They are all important things to be taken care of in the years ahead, though they are sometimes a convenient distraction from the wider issues at play. Just ask former chief executive David Gill.
OPINION: United set for new experiment without Martinez
"Trust me, that roof leaked when we were there, but we were top of the league, so it wasn't mentioned in the papers or media," Gill told the Rio Ferdinand Presents FIVE podcast.
"It leaked, whether it leaks a bit more now, I don't know, but all I'm saying is those sorts of things, success covers up a load of issues and we need to get back to that."

The first thing to point out is that, while Gill is right, it has now been 11 years since he left his position, and it still hasn't been sorted out. It clearly needs doing at some point. However, he is correct that as long as things are going well on the pitch, a lot of the off-field matters are forgotten about amid more pressing issues.

United might not be the best in class anymore, yet they are still judged by those standards. The smallest flaws are blown out of proportion when, at other clubs, they won't even be reported on. And issues that were present even during their success under Sir Alex Ferguson are now used to push a narrative of a club in decline.

It is very easy to pile on the misery whenever United are in a perceived crisis by pointing out their dated training facilities and going overboard with criticism of their stadium. Sure, they are both past their best when compared with more modern builds, but Old Trafford's leaky roof and Cristiano Ronaldo's criticism of the training ground are not the reason why they haven't won a Premier League title since Gill left.

They do serve as a timely reminder of the long-term project Ratcliffe will hope to oversee at his boyhood club, though his reign will ultimately be judged a success by whether or not he brings success back to the pitch. It's probable Ineos will arrive at a time when they won't benefit financially from Champions League qualification, and they'll need to sell in order to abide by Financial Fair Play rules this summer in addition to buying.
